LOAN AND PROJECT SUMMARY 

People’s Republic of China (PRC) 
 
Targeting Classification: Targeted intervention  
Sector: Water supply sanitation and waste management 
Subsector: Sanitation and waste management   
Themes: Environmental sustainability, sustainable economic              
growth 
Subthemes: Urban environmental improvement, fostering physical    
infrastructure development         
 
Category A. An environmental impact assessment (EIA) was undertaken. 
The summary EIA was circulated to the Asian Development Bank (ADB) 
Board  along  with  the  environmental  management  plan  on  9  February 
2006, and uploaded onto the ADB website on 15 February 2006. 
 

 
Project Description  The Project is a key urban infrastructure initiative of the Wuhan municipal 
government (WMG). It is classified as a “targeted intervention” because it 
contributes  to  achieving  Millennium  Development  Goal  7,  Target  10, 
which calls for halving, by 2015, the proportion of people without access 
to  safe  drinking  water  and  improved  sanitation.  The  Project  will  help 
Wuhan, the capital city of Hubei Province, in (i) reducing water pollution;  
(ii) protecting water resources; (iii) alleviating economic losses and social 
hardship  from  localized  flooding;  (iv)  promoting  sustainable  economic 
development;  and  (v)  improving  the  environment,  living  conditions,  and 
public  health  standards.  Wuhan  Municipality  has  a  population  of  7.8 
million, and an urban center population of 3.8 million. The Project includes 
four  components  or  outputs: 
into 
nine  major  activities  grouped 
(i) municipal  wastewater  management  in  urban  Wuhan,  (ii)  municipal 
(iii)  stormwater 
wastewater  management 
management,  and  (iv) 
targeted 
in  wastewater  and  stormwater 
capacity  building  and 
management. The Project supports the Government’s 10th and 11th Five-
Year  Plans,  to  improve  living  conditions  and  health  in  the  cities  of  the 
PRC and promote their sustainable economic development. 
 
Wuhan  is  strategically  located  at  the  confluence  of  the  Changjiang 
(Yangtze  River)  and  Han  River,  in  central  PRC.  Wuhan  has  abundant 
water resources including many rivers and lakes, which together take up 
about one quarter of the urban and suburban areas. 
 
Despite  the  abundant  water  resources,  however,  rapid  economic  growth 
and  continuing  urbanization  over  the  last  25  years  in  Wuhan  have 
resulted  in  inadequate  urban  infrastructure,  and  placed  pressure  on 
overloaded 
the 
Changjiang  has  decreased  significantly  over  the  last  15  years  mainly 
because  of  the  wastewater  discharge  from  the  city.  In  2004,  about  2.0 
million  cubic  meters  (m3)  per  day  of  wastewater  was  generated,  but  the 
four wastewater treatment plants (WWTPs) have the capacity to treat only 
27% of this quantity. Surface waters have been seriously polluted: 56% of

the rivers and 89% of the lakes in Wuhan are polluted. Accordingly, WMG 
is  implementing  the  city’s  strategic  wastewater  master  plan  to  meet 
national  environmental  targets  and  achieve  a  wastewater  treatment  rate 
of  80%  by  2010.  The  wastewater  master  plan  includes  the  phased  and 
coordinated construction of WWTPs and sewer networks with local funds 
and  assistance  from  ADB,  World  Bank,  and  bilateral  sources.  The 
ongoing  ADB  Wuhan  Wastewater  Management  Project  (WWMP), 
approved  in  2003,  together  with  other  ongoing  wastewater  treatment 
projects,  will  increase  Wuhan’s  WWTP  capacity  by  2008  to  70%  of  the 
wastewater  generated.  The  proposed  Project  is  not  a  stand-alone 
investment but an integral part of the basin-wide Yangtze water resources 
management  initiative,  the  Wuhan  city  urban  development  plan,  the 
Wuhan  wastewater  master  plan,  and  the  Wuhan  stormwater  drainage 
master  plan.  The  proposed  Project  will  provide  the  10%  additional 
capacity  critical  to  achieving  by  2010  the  city’s  target  of  80%  of  the 
wastewater generated. 
  
The built-up areas in Wuhan are mostly below the average flood level of 
the  Yangtze  and  Han  rivers.  Protected  by  flood  control  bunds,  Wuhan 
pumps  out  stormwater  to  the  rivers  during  the  wet  season.  The  distinct 
seasonal  variation  and  heavy  summer  rains,  however,  place  the  urban 
drainage  system  under  stress:  sewers  overflow  and  become  major 
sources of water pollution. Moreover, flooding in the urban areas is often 
serious  because  of  the  aging  and  inadequately  maintained  drainage 
network  and  under-capacity  pumping  stations.  Faced  with  a  growing 
deficit  in  infrastructure,  services,  and  environmental  management,  the 
WMG  is  planning  a  comprehensive  urban  drainage  and  flood  control 
program until 2010.  
 
The  impact  of  the  Project  is  to  improve  the  urban  environment,  public 
health,  and  the  quality  of  life  of  urban  and  suburban  residents  and 
businesses in Wuhan city. The outcome of the Project is better-managed 
surface  water  resources  through  (i)  improved  and  expanded  wastewater 
services  in  the  urban  area  of  Wuhan  and  the  suburban  area  of  Caidian 
and  Dongxihu, 
to  basin-wide  pollution 
prevention and control, (iii) improved water quality in rivers and lakes and 
in  downstream  reaches  of  Yangtze  River;  (iv)  reduced  flooding  in 
stormwater  drainage  areas  in  Qiaokouqu  district  and  Yangsigang  and 
Liujiao  road,  (v)  more  efficient  and  better-managed 
implementing 
agencies,  and  (vi)  better  cost  recovery  through  a  rationalized  tariff 
structure with gradual increases to achieve cost recovery. 
 
The  investment  cost  of  the  project  is  estimated  at  $266.4  million 
equivalent, including taxes and duties.

ADB will provide a loan of $100 million to finance 38% of the project cost 
including  financing  charges  during  construction.  The  Government  will 
finance  62%  through  a  combination  of  wastewater  tariffs,  WMG  budget 
sources, and domestic loans from PRC banks. 
 
ADB’s  loan  of  $100  million  will  come  from  its  ordinary  capital  resources 
and will be provided under ADB’s London interbank offered rate (LIBOR)–
based  lending  facility  for  US  dollar  loans.  The  loan  will  have  a  25-year 
term including a grace period of 5 years, an interest rate based on ADB’s 
LIBOR-based lending, a commitment charge of 0.75% per year, and such 
other terms and conditions as set forth in the draft Loan Agreement.  
 
The  Government  of  the  PRC  will  relend  the  loan  proceeds  to  the  Hubei 
provincial  government  (HPG),  which  will  on-lend  the  loan  proceeds  to 
WMG, the Executing Agency, on the same terms and conditions as those 
of  the  ADB  loan.  Part  of  the  loan  proceeds  will  be  on-lent  to  the  Wuhan 
Drainage  Company  (WDC),  the  Implementing  Agency  (IA)  for  the 
wastewater component, on the same terms and conditions as those of the 
ADB  loan.  The  balance  of  the  loan  will  be  applied  directly  by  Wuhan 
Urban  Construction  Foundation  (WUCF),  the  IA  for  the  stormwater 
component,  on  behalf  of  WMG.  The  end-borrowers  will  assume  the 
foreign exchange and interest rate variation risks of the ADB loan. 
 
Until 30 June 2011  

 
31 December 2010 

 
A project leading group (PLG) has been established. It is headed by the 
vice  mayor  of  WMG  and  comprises  representatives 
from  Wuhan 
Municipal’s  Development  and  Reform  Commission,  Construction 
Commission, Finance Bureau, Planning Bureau, Environmental Protection 
Bureau,  Water  Affairs  Bureau,  Price  Bureau,  WDC,  WUCF,  and  Caidian 
and  Dongxihu  district  governments.  The  PLG  will  provide  overall  policy 
guidance,  facilitate  interagency  coordination,  and  resolve  institutional 
problems  that  could  affect  project  implementation.  The  ongoing  WWMP 
project  management  office  (WPMO)  will  be  retained for  the proposed

Procurement  will  be  coursed  through  international  competitive  bidding, 
national  competitive  bidding,  or  shopping  procedures  as  determined  by 
the particular circumstances of each contract package. In accordance with 
ADB’s  Procurement  Guidelines,  foreign  contractors  may  participate  in

About  24  person-months  of  international  consultants  and  150  person-
months  of  domestic  consultants,  to  be  funded  under  the  Project,  will  be 
required  to  support  the  WPMO  and  IAs  in  project  implementation  and 
capacity  building.  The  scope  and  extent  of  consulting  services  takes 
account of the consulting support under WWMP and the specific needs of 
the  Project.  Consulting  services  will  be  provided  in  the  following  specific 
areas:  (i)  development  of  a  sludge  management  strategy  for  Wuhan,  (ii) 
investigation  and  control  of  inflow  and  infiltration  into  the  wastewater 
collection  network,  (iii)  assistance  with  private  sector  participation 
initiatives,  (iv)  financial  management,  (v)  operation  and  maintenance 
improvements, and (vi) extended development of water quality modeling. 
The  international  consultants  will  also  provide  training  and  capacity 
building in wastewater management and treatment planning, water quality 
management,  financial  management,  and  environmental  monitoring  and 
management.  The  consultants  will  be  recruited  according  to  ADB’s 
Guidelines on the Use of Consultants.   
 
The  Project  will  benefit  more  than  3  million  urban  residents  of  Wuhan, 
whose  living  conditions  and  public  health  standards  will  improve  as  a 
result of (i) reduced pollution of Wuhan’s surface water, (ii) protection from 
flooding  and  elimination  of  hazards  associated  with  poor  drainage,  and 
(iii) reduction in the incidence of waterborne infectious diseases below the 
2005  level  of  73  per  1,000  persons.  The  Project  will  improve  the 
management  of  surface  water  resources  in  Wuhan  by  (i)  achieving  the 
goal  of  80%  wastewater  treatment  rate  in  Wuhan  by  2010  and  thereby 
significantly  reducing  annual  pollution  loads  in  the  Yangtze  River  basin 
(YRB), (ii) significantly reducing flooding in the urban areas, (iii) increasing 
the  efficiency  and  management  capacity  of  the  IAs;  and  (iv)  improving 
cost  recovery  through  a  better  tariff  structure,  with  gradual  increases  to 
achieve  cost  recovery.  The  water  quality  improvements  in  the  Wuhan 
section  of

The Project will create at least 222 full-time permanent jobs with the WDC 
for the operation of the facilities, 5,000 person-years of work during the 5-
year  construction  period,  and  130  other 
jobs 
throughout  the  municipality.  About  40%  of  the  construction  jobs  will  be 
filled  by  the  poor  and  vulnerable,  including  unemployed  persons,  rural 
migrants,  and  women.  Public  health  benefits  will  accrue  through  an 
estimated  reduction  in  waterborne  disease  episodes  by  an  average  of 
8,000  cases  per  year.  The 
treatment 
infrastructure  directly  from  wastewater  tariff  increases  will  have  a 
demonstration  impact  on  wastewater  tariff  reform  in  both  the  PRC  and 
elsewhere  in  Asia.  The  Project  is  technically  sound,  affordable  to 
beneficiaries, and financially and economically viable.  
 
The Project does not have any unusual technical risks, with conventional 
engineering  designs  that  are  robust  and  with  a  proven  record  of  reliable 
performance.  Potential  financial  and  commercial  risks  related  to  the 
Project include: (i) failure to meet the cash or equity transfers required to 
build the project facilities, and (ii) failure by WMG to increase the tariffs to 
ensure  continuing  cost  recovery.  The  major  assumptions  are  that  the 
Wuhan  wastewater  and  stormwater  management  plans  are  effectively 
implemented.  The  project  management  risk  will  be  mitigated  by  the 
existence of the PLG within WMG, and coordination by WPMO, which is 
strong  and  experienced  in  overseeing  large  internationally  funded 
projects.  The  potential  financial  and  policy  risks  will  be  mitigated  by 
assurances related to the financial and managerial autonomy of WDC and 
by WMG’s commitment to ensuring full financing for stormwater operation 
and  maintenance.  The  risks  associated  with  lack  of  local  funding  will  be 
addressed  by  the  assurance  from  WMG  that  it  will  meet  any  cost 
increases,  and  guarantee  the  required  equity  injections  to  meet  the 
financing requirements of the Project.

I. 

THE PROPOSAL 

 
1. 
I submit for your approval the following report and recommendation on a proposed loan 
to  the  People's  Republic  of  China  (PRC)  for  the  Wuhan  Wastewater  and  Stormwater 
Management Project.  
 
2. 
In  line  with  its  long-term  goals  for  the  urban  sector  of  improving  living  conditions, 
minimizing  flooding,  protecting  water  resources,  and  increasing  the  coverage  of  wastewater 
treatment, the Government of the PRC requested the Asian Development Bank (ADB) to assist 
in  implementing  wastewater  and  stormwater  projects  in  Wuhan  in  central  PRC.  The  proposed 
Project  is  a  natural  follow-on  to  the  ADB-financed  Wuhan  Wastewater  Management  Project 
(WWMP),1 which is now being implemented. The Project is consistent with ADB’s water policy2 
and will help the PRC achieve Millennium Development Goal (MDG) 7, target 10. It supports the 
3Rs (reduce, reuse, recycle) initiative announced by the G8, to which the PRC is a party. This 
report is based on the findings of the loan fact-finding mission and discussions with the central 
and  local  governments,  relevant  agencies,  and  community  organizations.  The  design  and 
monitoring framework of the Project is in Appendix 1. 
 

II. 

RATIONALE: SECTOR PERFORMANCE, PROBLEMS, AND OPPORTUNITIES 

Performance Indicators and Analysis 

 
A. 
 
3. 
Economic  growth  in  the  PRC  has  averaged  8%  yearly  over  the  last  20  years  and  is 
projected  to  average  7%  over  the  next  5  years.  The  urban  population  grew  from  about  190 
million in 1980 to about 543 million in 2004, about 41.8% of the total population that year, and is 
expected to rise further to 700 million, or 50% of the total, by 2030.3 The Government’s Agenda 
for  Economic  Reform  and  Social  Development  in  the  New  Century  aims  to  accelerate 
urbanization  and  the  development  of  large,  medium,  and  small  cities  and  small  towns.  This 
urbanization process will continue to increase the demand for all urban services. In particular, it 
will severely strain the physical and financial capacity of most cities to provide adequate urban 
infrastructure including wastewater and stormwater facilities. Without significant investment, the 
quality of life of urban residents will deteriorate, the urban environment will suffer degradation, 
and inefficiencies will hamper economic development. 
 
4. 
The  PRC’s  urban  areas  face  environmental  threats  from  the  pollution  of  rivers,  lakes, 
and underground aquifers by untreated water. In 2004, about 48.2 billion cubic meters (m3) of 
wastewater  was  generated,  of  which  about  54%  came  from  municipal  sources  and  46%  from 
industrial sources. About 90% of industrial wastewater is treated before being discharged into a 
municipal sewer. Municipal wastewater is a major contributor to the pollution of the PRC’s rivers 
and lakes. In 2004, only about 45.2% (34% in 1999) of urban wastewater was treated; the rest 
was discharged untreated to rivers and lakes. About 41.8% of the water in the seven major river 
basins 4 does  not  meet  the  Class  III 5 standard  of  the  PRC  for  water  quality.  Surface  water

sources serving municipal water supply systems are polluted to levels unacceptable under this 
standard.  To  address  the  problem  of  pollution  of  lakes  and  rivers,  the  following  actions  are 
needed:  (i) strengthen  laws,  regulations,  and  institutions  to  address  trans-jurisdiction  pollution; 
(ii)  adopt  river  basin  management  approaches  to  water  resources  management;  (iii)  reduce 
non–point  source  pollution;  (iv)  continue  investing  in  municipal  wastewater  treatment  plants 
(WWTPs)  to  mitigate  the  polluting  effects  of  rapid  urbanization;  (v)  diversify  financing  sources 
for  environmental  investments;  and  (vi)  continue  institutional  and  financial  reforms  to  facilitate 
balanced economic growth and environmental sustainability. Significant investments throughout 
the  country  are  needed  to  solve  water  shortages,  ensure  a  supply  of  clean  drinking  water, 
expand wastewater treatment capacity, and reduce flooding. 
 
5. 
Recognizing that adequate environmental protection and pollution controls are essential 
for  sustainable  economic  growth,  the  Government  has  made  environmental  protection  a 
national priority in its development strategy. Besides passing environmental protection laws and 
implementing  regulations  that  emphasize  prevention,  the  “polluter  pays”  principle,  and 
decentralized  environmental  management,  the  Government  has  also  undertaken  many 
programs  including  several  for  wastewater  management. 6  Industries  were  ordered  to  treat 
wastewater to national wastewater discharge standards by the end of 2000. Municipalities have 
been required under successive 5-year plans to address wastewater collection, treatment, and 
disposal.  Pollution  control  plans  have  been  developed  and  partially  implemented  for  the  key 
river basins. Government policies require urban environmental pollution and ecological damage 
to be controlled by 2010, and by that year major cities, such as provincial capitals, are expected 
under  recent  state  guidelines  to  have  wastewater  treatment  rates  of  at  least  80%.7 The  State 
Environmental  Protection  Administration  (SEPA)  requires  all  new  WWTPs  to  provide  at  least 
secondary wastewater treatment. The treatment level required is also dependent on the quality 
of the receiving water. 
 
6. 
The  Government  has  accorded  priority  in  its  11th  Five-Year  Plan  (2006–2010)  to 
addressing  wastewater  treatment  issues  through  policy  reform,  increased  investment,  and 
improved  urban  infrastructure  management.  The  Government’s  strategy  focuses  on  (i) 
protecting  water  sources  by  controlling  industrial  and  other  pollution,  (ii) introducing  water-
efficient  technologies  and  operations,  and  (iii)  using  appropriate  pricing  mechanisms  to 
encourage  conservation  and  generate  the  necessary  funds  for  operation,  maintenance,  and 
investment.  The  Government’s  economic  and  enterprise  reform  programs  require  that  all 
wastewater  projects  be  financially  sustainable  and  capable  of  cost  recovery.  In  contrast, 
stormwater drainage is considered a public service to be financed from government revenues. 
The wastewater and stormwater sector analysis is given in Appendix 2. 
 
7. 
Wuhan’s extensive water bodies take up one fourth of the urban built-up area. In 2004, 
wastewater  discharge  was  about  2  million  m3/day,  47%  of  which  was  industrial  wastewater. 
There are four WWTPs in Wuhan, most of which provide only primary treatment and are able to 
treat  only  27%  of  the  wastewater  generated.  The  investments  being  made  under  the  ongoing 
WWMP, together with wastewater treatment projects assisted by the World Bank8 and bilateral

Analysis of Key Problems and Opportunities 

aid  agencies,  will  help  increase  this  percentage  to  70%  by  2008.  With  the  Project,  the 
wastewater treatment rate will reach the required 80% by 2010.9 The Wuhan wastewater master 
plan  and  the  contributions  to  the  overall  treatment  rate  by  the  multilateral  and  bilateral  aid 
agencies and local interventions are detailed in Supplementary Appendix A. The large quantity 
of  untreated  and  primary-treated  wastewater  discharged  into  rivers  and  lakes  has  caused  a 
significant deterioration in water quality, which must be reversed. The entire Wuhan stretch of 
the Yangtze and Han rivers is on the borderline between Class III and Class IV water quality. 
Many lakes in Wuhan are below Class V. Further, the future operation of the South–North Water 
Transfer  Project  (middle  route)  will  significantly  reduce  water  flows  in  the  Han  River  and  thus 
reduce its assimilative capacity. 
 
B. 
 
8. 
Project  Background.  Urban  wastewater  management  in  the  PRC  was  traditionally 
based on the use of septic tanks. Rapid urbanization makes that approach inadequate. Over the 
past decade there has been a fundamental shift toward an integrated approach to urban water 
management  and  the  use  of  centralized  municipal  wastewater  treatment.  Although  there  has 
been much improvement, wastewater management in the PRC still presents many opportunities 
to reduce water pollution, protect water resources, promote sustainable economic development, 
and  improve  the  living  conditions  and  public  health  of  urban  and  suburban  residents.  Key 
include:  (i)  worsening  surface  water  quality, 
problems  and  opportunities 
(ii) inadequate  wastewater  treatment  capacity,  (iii)  inadequate  stormwater  discharge  capacity, 
(iv) the need to extend improvements to suburban areas, and (v) the need for ongoing financial 
and institutional reforms to make urban services genuinely sustainable. 
 
9. 
Wuhan, in the central region of the PRC, is the capital of Hubei Province. It lies on the 
Jianghan  Plain,  where  the  Han  River  joins  the  Yangtze  River.  It  is  strategically  located  about 
halfway  along  the  length  of  the  Yangtze  River  and  is  a  center  of  communications,  education, 
culture,  economy,  trade,  transportation,  and  industry.  Wuhan  covers  an  area  of  8,467  square 
kilometers (km2), including an urban built-up area of 211 km2. As of 2004, the municipality had a 
population  of  about  7.8  million.  Wuhan’s  urban  area  is  divided  into  three  parts  (Hankou, 
Hanyang, and Wuchang) by the Yangtze and Han rivers. The municipality has seven urban and 
six suburban districts. Wuhan has abundant water resources, including the Yangtze, Han, and 
Fu rivers, and many lakes, which together take up 2,144 km2, or one quarter of the urban and 
suburban areas.  
 
10.  Water  Quality  in  the  Yangtze  River  Basin.  The  Yangtze  River  basin  (YRB)  is  the 
largest  river  basin  in  the  PRC.  The  Changjiang  Water  Resources  Commission,  which  has 
overall responsibility for managing water resources within the YRB, has developed a basin-wide 
management  plan  providing  a  framework  for  managing  water  resources  within  the  river  basin. 
The plan cites the deteriorating water quality of Yangtze River despite what is often seen to be 
the river’s high assimilative capacity. The deterioration in water quality is the cumulative effect of 
many  point  and  nonpoint  discharges.  Effects  are  felt  throughout  the  downstream  reaches  and 
the East China Sea. The plan sets out a number of general pollution control targets with specific 
targets to be developed by individual provinces and cities.  
 
11. 
Project  Rationale.  Despite  the  abundant  water  resources, rapid  economic  growth  and 
continuing  urbanization  over  the  last  25  years  in  Wuhan  have  resulted  in  inadequate  urban 
                                                 
9  The  Wuhan  strategic  wastewater  master  plan  aims  to  achieve  80%  wastewater  treatment  rate  by  2010  in    
accordance  with  state  guidelines.  Twenty-five  percent  is  expected  to  be  achieved  through  ADB’s  Wuhan 
Wastewater  Management  Project,  35%  with  the  help  of  the  World  Bank,  6%  with  Finnish  and  Polish  assistance, 
and 4% through WMG’s own efforts. The final critical 10% increase will come from the proposed Project. 

 

 4 

 

 

infrastructure, and placed pressure on overload facilities. The YRB is the PRC’s largest and it 
receives  the  highest  volume  of  wastewater  of  the  seven  major  rivers  in  the  country.  The 
cumulative  effect  of  innumerable  point  and  non-point  discharge  is  deteriorating  water  quality. 
Effects of the cumulative pollution are felt throughout the downstream reaches of the Yangtze 
River. Water quality in Wuhan section of the Yangtze River has decreased significantly over the 
last 15 years mainly due to the wastewater discharge from the city. In 2004, about 2.0 million 
m3/day of wastewater was generated, but the four WWTPs could treat only 27% of this volume. 
About  58%  of  the  rivers  and  89%  of  the  lakes  in  Wuhan  are  polluted.  At  the  same  time,  the 
demand for water for domestic and industrial use is steadily increasing.  
 
12. 
The  built-up  areas  in  Wuhan  are  mostly  below  the  average  flood  level  of  the  Yangtze 
and  Han  rivers.  Protected  by  flood  control  bunds,  Wuhan  pumps  out  stormwater  to  the  rivers 
during  the  wet  season.  But  its  location  in  the  subtropical  monsoon  climate  zone,  distinct 
seasonal variation, and heavy summer rains place Wuhan’s aging urban drainage system under 
great  stress.  Flooding  is  frequent  and  severe,  and  combined  sewer  overflows  also  become 
major sources of water pollution. The increasing water pollution creates water supply problems 
and economic losses, and affects development and economic growth.  
 
13. 
The proposed Project is not a stand-alone investment but an integrated part of the basin-
wide Yangtze water resources management initiative, the Wuhan city urban development plan, 
the  Wuhan  municipal  wastewater  master  plan,  and  the  Wuhan  stormwater  drainage  master 
plan.  The  Wuhan  municipal  government  (WMG)  is  now  implementing  its  wastewater  master 
plan  and  will  install  more  WWTPs  to  raise  the  wastewater  treatment  rate  to  80%  by  2010  as 
required  in  the  state  guidelines.  The  wastewater  master  plan  includes  the  phased  and  well-
coordinated construction of WWTPs and sewer networks using local funds and assistance from 
ADB, the World Bank, and bilateral sources including Finland and Poland. ADB’s WWMP, which 
is  now  being  implemented,  along  with  other  ongoing  wastewater  treatments  supported  by  the 
World  Bank  and  bilateral  aid  agencies,  will  increase  Wuhan’s  WWTP  capacity  to  70%  of  the 
wastewater  generated  by  2008.  The  proposed  Project  will  provide  the  final  10%  increase  in 
capacity that Wuhan needs to achieve the 80% wastewater treatment target by 2010. WMG is 
also  implementing  its  stormwater  and  drainage  master  plan  to  significantly  increase  the 
drainage  network  coverage  in  the  municipality  by  2010.  The  proposed  Project  will  contribute 
significantly  to  achieving  the  targets  set  in  the  Wuhan  wastewater  master  plan  and  the 
stormwater  drainage  master  plan.  It  will  benefit  residents  of  Wuhan  and  those  living 
downstream. 
 
The  Project  will  promote  sustainable  economic  growth  through  sustainable  wastewater 
14. 
management  in  Wuhan  and  water  resource  protection  in  the  Wuhan  section  of  the  Yangtze 
River. It will also give specific attention to stormwater management, as frequent heavy summer 
rains cause serious local flooding. The Project will address these major issues: (i) deterioration 
in the quality of surface water and the urban environment, (ii) ineffective regulation of municipal 
and  industrial  wastewater  discharges,  (iii)  economic  losses  and  disruption  to  livelihoods  from 
frequent  local  flooding,  (iv)  ill  health  and  low  living  standards  among  the  poor,  (v)  lack  of 
integrated wastewater management, and (vi) inefficient service which will be addressed through 
promotion of competition and private sector participation (PSP). 

 
15. 
Policy  Dialogue.  The  Project  supports  and  strengthens  ADB  policy  dialogue  and 
initiatives with the Government in several key areas as indicated in Appendix 3. ADB supported 
the reform of water supply tariffs through two completed water tariff studies10 with the Ministry of 

                                                 
10   ADB. 1997. Technical Assistance to the People’s Republic of  China  for  Water  Supply Tariff Study.  Manila;  and 
     ADB. 1999. Technical Assistance to the People’s Republic of China  for Water Tariff Study II. Manila. 

                                     

 

 

 

 

 

                             

5

Construction,  under  which  the  National  Guidelines  on  Water  Tariffs  (NGWT)  were  developed, 
promulgated,  and  implemented.  Another  technical  assistance11 (TA)  involved  the  development 
of  national  guidelines  for  wastewater  tariffs,  including  tariff  calculation  methods  that  allow  for  
cost  recovery,  considering  affordability  and  social  constraints.  In  accordance  with  the  NGWT, 
Wuhan  held  a  public  hearing  in  November  2005  to  discuss  and  consider  the  Water  Supply 
Company’s  proposed  plan  to  increase  the  tap  water  tariff  in  the  central  urban  areas.12 WMG 
plans  to  hold  a  similar  public  hearing  in  the  fourth  quarter  of  2006  to  discuss  a  proposed 
increase in wastewater tariffs from CNY0.80 per m3 to about CNY1.00 per m3, starting in 2007. 
Demonstrating  its  progressive  approach  to  tariff  reforms,  WMG  issued  a  policy  statement  in 
March 2006 indicating that wastewater tariffs would be introduced or increased in the suburban 
areas of Caidian and Dongxihu in 2006. Still another ADB TA to strengthen policy reform calls 
for  the  use  of  market-based  instruments  to  increase  PSP  in  public  utilities,  mainly  in  water 
supply,  and  wastewater  and  solid  waste  management.13 The  proposed  Project  will  create  the 
environment necessary for PSP by pursuing tariff reform, cost recovery, enterprise reform, and 
improved governance—all are prerequisites for private sector involvement.  

 
External Assistance. Since 1993, ADB has provided 14 loans (Appendix 4) to the PRC,  
16. 
totaling about $1.4 billion for urban wastewater management and water supply projects. It has 
also provided about $41 million for more than 40 TA studies to prepare the above projects, and 
to review and study key issues in water resources, urban water supply, wastewater treatment, 
and  pollution  control.  External  assistance  to  the  WMG  in  developing  and  implementing  its 
strategic  wastewater  master  plan  has  come  mainly  from  ADB,  the  World  Bank  and  the 
governments  of  Finland  and  Poland.  ADB,  the  World  Bank,  the  Japan  Bank  for  International 
Cooperation, and several aid agencies  have also extended financial and technical assistance to 
the  PRC  Government  in  urban  environmental  protection  and  management.  The  World  Bank 
alone has provided financial assistance for 26 urban environmental improvement, water supply, 
and wastewater management projects. 

 

Lessons  Learned.  ADB’s  loan  projects  in  the  PRC  have  generally  been  implemented 
17. 
well. 14  The  lessons  learned  from  ADB’s  post-evaluation  experience  in  water  supply  and 
sanitation highlight the importance of integrating both supply and demand concerns into project 
design.  Encouraging  broad  reforms,  such  as  commercial  management,  and  introducing 
competition  will  promote  efficient  and  responsive  delivery  of  water  supply  and  wastewater 
services. Appropriate pricing policies for water and sanitation services are also required. Other 
lessons learned include the need to (i) review technical designs thoroughly; (ii) draw up strategic 
master  plans  in  urban  development  and  environmental  management;  (iii)  consider  local 
conditions  and  constraints;  (iv)  give  enough  attention  to  sustainability;  (v)  have  good-
quality  and competent executing agencies to ensure the delivery of project benefits; (vi) support 
financial reform, particularly in establishing autonomous wastewater entities and tariff increases; 
(vii)  strengthen  institutions,  particularly  by  giving  them  managerial  autonomy;  (viii)  address 
regulatory  and  enforcement  issues;  (ix)  educate  the  public  in  environmental  improvement;  (x) 
train  utility  personnel;  (xi)  consult  the  public  and  involve  the  community;  (xii)  attend  early  to 
resettlement  issues;  and  (xiii)  support  public-private  partnerships  in  water  supply  and 
wastewater treatment.

18. 
A performance portfolio review of the water supply, sanitation, and waste management 
sector,  done  recently  by  the  PRC,  identified  successes  and  deficiencies,  and  lessons  learned 
from portfolio performance.15  Among the major issues identified were (i) delays in the start-up of 
projects and in procurement, (ii) weak institutional arrangements for project implementation and 
sustainable operations, and (iii) low proportion of civil works financing resulting in loan savings   
and cancellation of surplus loan amounts. These issues were reviewed in detail during project 
processing  and  the  lessons  learned  were  incorporated  in  the  project  design.  The  lessons 
learned from the ongoing ADB WWMP and the World Bank’s Hubei Urban Environment Project 
have  also  been  incorporated  in  the  design  of  the  proposed  Project.  Analysts  processing  the 
Project,  having  learned  from  experience,  (i) thoroughly  evaluated  the  technical  designs  and 
technologies; (ii) ensured an adequate debt-equity ratio for the Implementing Agencies (IAs); (iii) 
undertook rigorous sensitivity analysis of cash flows, and financial and economic analysis; and 
(iv) incorporated institutional strengthening measures to improve corporate governance, taking 
into  account  the  capacity-building  components  of  the  first  ADB-financed  WWMP  to  prevent 
duplication of effort. 
 

III. 

THE PROPOSED PROJECT 

Outputs 

Impact and Outcome 

 
A. 
 
19. 
The  impact  of  the  Project  is  to  improve  the  urban  environment,  public  health,  and  the 
quality of life of urban and suburban residents and businesses in Wuhan city. The outcome of 
the  Project  is  to  bring  about  better  management  of  surface  water  resources  in  Wuhan 
Municipality by (i) improving and expanding wastewater services in the urban areas of Wuhan 
and the suburban area of Caidian and Dongxihu, (ii) supporting integrated approaches to basin-
wide  pollution  prevention  and  control,  (iii)  improving  the  water  quality  of  rivers  and  lakes  in 
Wuhan  and  in  downstream  reaches  of  the  Yangtze  River,  (iv)  reducing  flooding  in  stormwater 
drainage areas in Qiaokouqu district and Yangsigang and Liujiao roads in Wuhan, (v) increasing 
the  efficiency  and  management  capacity  of  the  two  IAs, 16 and  (vi)  improving  cost  recovery 
through a rationalized tariff structure, with gradual increases to achieve cost recovery. 
 
B. 
 
20. 
The proposed Project comprises nine major activities grouped into four components or 
outputs  (Supplementary  Appendix  B):  (i)  municipal  wastewater  management  in  urban  Wuhan, 
(ii) municipal wastewater in suburban Wuhan, (iii) stormwater management, and (iv) institutional 
development.  The  structural  measures  include  new  and  upgraded  wastewater  treatment 
facilities,  collection  network  extension  and  rehabilitation,  and  larger-capacity  stormwater 
pumping stations, built to national design standards.  
 
21.  Municipal Wastewater Management in Urban Wuhan. This component will (i) expand 
and  upgrade  the  Erlangmiao  primary  WWTP  from  180,000  m3/day  to  240,000  m3/day  with 
secondary  treatment,  (ii)  increase  the  capacity  of  the  Nantaizi  Lake  secondary  WWTP  from 
100,000  m3/day  to  200,000  m3/day,  (iii)  upgrade  the  100,000  m3/day  Huangpu  Road 
pretreatment WWTP to a secondary treatment plant, and (iv) build sewer pipelines and pumping 
stations. 
 

                                                 
15   PRC: Water Supply, Sanitation and Waste Management Portfolio Performance Review. Final Report, July 2005.  
16  The IAs are (i) Wuhan Drainage Company Ltd. for the wastewater component; and (ii) Wuhan Urban Construction

7

22.  Municipal  Wastewater  Management  in  Suburban  Wuhan.  This component will build 
(i) a  secondary  50,000  m3/day  WWTP  at  Caidian  and  a  related  wastewater  collection  system 
comprising 4.6 km of pipelines and a pumping station; and (ii) a wastewater collection system in 
Dongxihu  comprising  15.6  km  of  sewer  pipelines,  9.8  km  of  box  culverts,  and  five  pumping 
stations. The urban and suburban municipal wastewater components will significantly increase 
the volume of wastewater collected and treated and will help Wuhan achieve the required target 
of 80% wastewater treatment by 2010. The wastewater component is consistent with the overall 
pollution  load  reduction  targets  of  the  Yangtze  River  water  resources  protection  plan,  and  the 
Wuhan wastewater master plan. The component will improve the quality of water resources, the 
local  environment,  and  health  by  reducing  the  pollution  of  watercourses,  and  it  will  reduce 
downstream pollution in the YRB. 
 
Stormwater  Management.  The  component  will  (i)  improve  the  Luojia  road  drainage 
23. 
works in Wuchang with channel renovation for Luojiangang and Shahugang, and increase the 
related pump station capacity by 55 m3 per second; (ii) increase the capacity of the Yangsigang 
pumping station in Hangyang by 20 m3 per second and building 1.34 km of stormwater pipelines 
and 1.9 km of box culverts; (iii) connect three key drainage control gates in Dongxihu by building 
3.9 km of box culverts and 4.3 km of open channel, and rehabilitating 4.5 km of open channel; 
and (iv) increase the pumping capacity of the Dongxihu–Changqing pumping station by 135 m3 
per second. The stormwater component will enhance the performance of the drainage system 
and  the  combined  sewer  overflows,  and  significantly  improve  flood  control  in  several  urban 
areas of Wuhan.  
 
24. 
Institutional  Development. This component will (i) support the further development of 
the regional water quality model,17 which has begun under the ongoing WWMP; (ii) carry out a 
pilot  inflow  and  infiltration  study  and  a  sludge  management  study;  and  (iii)  provide  training  in 
financial management and operation of wastewater and stormwater facilities using international 
best  practices.  The  Project  will  strengthen  institutional  capacity  to  facilitate  the  adoption  of  an 
integrated approach to water resource management including pollution and flood control. 
 
C. 
 
The  Project  supports  and  strengthens  ADB  policy  dialogue  and  initiatives  with  the 
25. 
Government  in  several  key  areas  including:  (i)  cost  recovery  and  tariff  reform,  (ii)  wastewater 
management, (iii) water conservation, (iv) corporate governance and enterprise reform, (v) safe 
and  reliable  arrangements  for  sludge  disposal,  (vi)  trans-boundary  pollution  prevention  and 
control, and (vii) stormwater management. The funding of the Project directly from wastewater 
tariffs is a major reform in line with ADB water policy. WMG is committed to generating funds18 
from wastewater tariffs to finance the wastewater component of the Project.  
 
The  Project  will  build  on  the  WWMP  tariff  and  institutional  reforms  and  help  WMG  to 
26. 
develop  a  structured  and  rational  approach  for  the  private  sector  to  participate  in  both 
wastewater  and  stormwater  management.  Project  preparations  have  identified  a  possible 
national initiative to review and improve the financing and management of stormwater services 
in the PRC.

F. 

Implementation Arrangements  

1. 

Project Management 

 
31. 
The  Executing  Agency  will  be  WMG.  A  project  leading  group  (PLG)  has  been 
established;  it  is  headed  by  the  vice  mayor  of  WMG  and  is  made  up  of  representatives  from 
Wuhan Municipal’s Development and Reform Commission, Construction Commission, Finance 
Bureau,  Planning  Bureau,  Environmental  Protection  Bureau,  Water  Affairs  Bureau,  Price 
Bureau,  WDC,  WUCF,  and  Caidian  and  Dongxihu  district  governments.  The  PLG  will  provide 
overall  policy  guidance,  facilitate  interagency  coordination,  and  resolve  institutional  problems 
that  could  affect  project  implementation.  The  project  management  office  for  the  WWMP 
(WPMO) will be retained for the proposed Project. The WPMO will act as the secretariat of the 
PLG  and  coordinate  and  monitor  implementation  activities  of  WDC  and  WUCF.  The  internal 
organization  of  the  IAs  is  outlined  in  Supplementary  Appendix  D.  The  difference  in 
implementation  arrangements  for  the  two  components  reflects  the  different  financing  and 
institutional  arrangements  for  wastewater  and  stormwater  management  in  Wuhan,  and  in  the 
PRC in general.  
 
32.  WDC will be the implementing agency responsible for the wastewater component of the 
Project  and  the  institutional  development  activities  associated  with  this  component.  WDC  is  a 
limited  liability  company  incorporated  under  the  PRC  Company  Law  and  is  also  the  IA  for  the 

 

 10 

 

 

ongoing WWMP. It is therefore experienced in ADB project implementation and has a board of 
directors  overseeing  the  financial  and  operational  matters  of  the  WDC  including:  (i) hiring  and 
firing of senior management, (ii) staffing and remuneration plans, (iii) annual construction plans 
and progress of construction, (iv) annual financial budgets, (v) investment plans and accounts of 
WDC  and  the  related  subprojects,  and  (vi)  procurement  of  major  equipment  and  civil  works 
contracts.  
 
33.  WUCF will be the implementing agency responsible for the stormwater component of the 
Project and the institutional development activities associated with this component. WUCF is a 
government  agency  responsible  to  WMG  for  coordinating  the  implementation  of  government-
sponsored  urban  infrastructure  projects  that  are  largely  or  wholly  financed  with  government 
revenues.  WUCF  does  not  operate  or  provide  services,  however,  and  its  responsibilities  for 
asset  management  end  after  the  assets  are  commissioned.  At  that  time  the  public  assets  are 
passed  on  to  the  relevant  government  department,  which  in  this  case  will  be  the  Wuhan 
Municipal  Water  Authority  (for  the  pumping  stations)  and  its  subordinate  units  at  the  district 
government level (for storm water drainage, etc). These arrangements are commonplace in the 
PRC. 
   
34. 
The financial, technical, and institutional capacity of both IAs was assessed. The WPMO 
and  IAs  already  have  staff  trained  in  project  management.  WUCF  will,  however,  need  some 
training  in  the  relevant  ADB  procedures  during  project  implementation.  WDC  will  directly 
manage  construction,  but  WUCF  will  outsource  this  activity  to  an  experienced  and  qualified 
construction  management  company.  Once  the  stormwater  facilities  are  built,  WUCF  will  pass 
them  on  to  the  district  water  bureau  for  operation  and  maintenance.  Both  IAs  will  retain  the 
services  of  design  institutes  and  specialist  procurement  agencies  to  assist  in  implementation. 
With  the  help  of  international  consultants,  the  WPMO  and  the  IAs  will  develop  expertise  in: 
(i) efficient  operation  of  the  wastewater  and  stormwater  facilities;  (ii)  functional  areas  of 
administration,  finance  and  accounting,  and  business  planning;  and  (iii)  use  of  PSP  and 
outsourcing contracts. WDC already receives consulting services support under the WWMP, so 
capacity  building  will  be  weighted  in  favor  of  the  stormwater  component.  The  institutional  and 
capacity-building measures are detailed in Supplementary Appendix E. 
 
The  internal  controls  and  accounting  and  auditing  procedures  of  WDC  were  reviewed 
35. 
through  a  financial  management  assessment  (FMA),  as  indicated  in  Appendix  7  and 
Supplementary Appendix F. This assessment and the WMG’s previous experience in managing 
ADB  loans  confirmed  the  adequacy  of  their  financial  management  practices  for  both  the 
construction  and  operational  phase  of  the  Project.  But  discussions  concerning  the  financial 
management of stormwater management services indicated a need for improvement. During the 
policy  dialogue,  the  WMG  requested  assistance  in  financial  management,  particularly  in  the 
review of applications for water and wastewater tariff adjustments. Both of these requirements 
are  addressed  through  the  provision  of  consulting  services.  On  the  basis  of  a  comprehensive 
assessment of the IAs’ financial and managerial capabilities, the Project is deemed sustainable, 
as  indicated  in  Appendix  8.  WDC’s  financial  performance  was  also  evaluated;  its  current  and 
projected  financial  position  is  in  Supplementary  Appendices  G  and  H.  The  IAs’  technical  and 
institutional  capacities  were  assessed  as  well,  and  were  found  to  be  adequate  for  project 
implementation.

Procurement 

 
37. 
Equipment, materials and goods, and services financed under the loan will be procured 
in  accordance  to  ADB’s  Procurement  Guidelines  and  follow  ADB  procedures  for  international 
competitive  bidding  (ICB)  for  packages  each  with  a  value  greater  than  $1 million.  Packages 
valued at $1 million or less will be procured following national competitive bidding or shopping

IV. 

PROJECT BENEFITS, IMPACTS, ASSUMPTIONS, AND RISKS 

Project Benefits and Impacts 

 
A. 
 
47. 
The  Project  will  benefit  more  than  3  million  urban  residents  in  Wuhan  whose  living 
conditions  and  public  health  standards  will  improve  as  a  result  of  (i)  reduced  pollution  in 
Wuhan’s surface water, following the improvement of wastewater collection and the wastewater 
treatment  rate;  (ii)  protection  from  flooding  and  elimination  of  hazards  associated  with  poor 
drainage; and (iii) reduction in the incidence of waterborne infectious diseases below the 2005 
level  of  73  cases  per  1,000  persons.  The  health  impact  analysis  is  in  Supplementary 
Appendix  J. The Project will improve the management of surface water resources in Wuhan by 
(i)  achieving  the  goal  of  80%  wastewater  treatment  rate  in  Wuhan  by  2010;  (ii)  reducing  the 
annual  pollution  load  in  the  YRB  by  20,000  tons  biochemical  oxygen  demand,  36,000  tons 
chemical  oxygen  demand,  25,000  tons  suspended  solids,  3,000  tons  ammonia  nitrogen,  and 
340  tons  total  phosphorus,  by  2010;  (iii)  significantly  reducing  flooding  in  the  urban  areas; 
(iv) increasing  the  efficiency  and  management  capacity  of  the  IAs;  and  (iv)  improving  cost 
recovery through a better tariff structure, with gradual increases to achieve cost recovery.  
 
48. 
To  achieve  national  wastewater  treatment  targets,  WMG  will  build  a  new  WWTP  and 
upgrade  and  expand  three  WWTPs.  Upon  project  completion,  210,000  m3/day  treatment 
capacity will be added, and the four WWTPs will provide a total of 590,000 m3/day secondary 
treatment to the received wastewater to reach related national standards. The associated sewer 
networks  and  pumping  stations  will  also  be  built  to  accommodate  the  growth  in  wastewater 
flows to year 2015 in the project areas. The water quality improvements in the Wuhan section of 
the  YRB  will  also  contribute  to  integrated  water  resource  management  and  pollution  control, 
basin-wide management, and trans-boundary pollution prevention and control.  
 
The stormwater management component will add 102 cubic meters per second (m3/s) of 
49. 
drainage  pumping  capacity,  increasing  the  total  capacity  to  292  m3/s  to  accommodate  the 
anticipated  flood  flows  in  the  project  areas  by  the  year  2020.  To  improve  flood  control  in  the 
urban  areas  of  Wuhan,  this  component  will  improve  the  drainage-sewerage  network  by 
separating stormwater and wastewater flows into different systems and rehabilitating defective 
pipes.  Waterborne  diseases,  accidents,  injuries  and  loss  of  life,  and  damage  to  property, 
agriculture, and infrastructure will be minimized.

and  the  State  Council  Decision  to  Deepen  Reform  and  Strictly  Enforce  Land  Administration 
(28 November 2004).

2. 

Poverty Reduction 

 
The  Project  supports  the  achievement  of  the  Millennium  Development  Goal  (MDG)  for 
54. 
environmental sustainability (MDG  Goal 7 Target 10).  It will benefit directly 3 million, including 
0.24 million poor people, and indirectly 4 million people living within and downstream of Wuhan. 
The Project will reduce flooding and associated damages, improve sanitation and environmental 
conditions,  reduce  morbidity  and  mortality  from  waterborne  and  water-washed  diseases,  and 
reduce  the  associated  medical  costs  and  workdays  lost.  The  Project  is  estimated  to  reduce 
water-related  disease  by  an  average  of  8,000  cases  per  year  and  thus  save  5,800  workdays 
and CNY7.7 million (in net present value) in medical costs and lost earnings. 
 
55.  Women  and  the  poor  will  benefit  disproportionately  from  the  Project.  Poor  households 
and  vulnerable  groups  tend  to  reside  in  areas  with  poorer  service  levels  and  are  less  able  to 
cope with the disruption and illness caused by poor services. Reductions in flooding and illness 
will reduce women’s burden of work. A reduction in lost school days and workdays represents a 
key intervention in the poverty cycle. The adverse impacts of tariff adjustments on the poor are 
largely eliminated by existing tariff subsidies for poor households to offset the cost of water and 
wastewater  services.  These  subsidies  are  in  addition  to  the  Minimum  Living  Security  Scheme 
subsidies.24 
 
56. 
The Project will provide 5,000 person-years of work over the 5-year construction period 
and economic spin-off effects of 8,100 person-years of work. About 40% of the construction jobs 
will  be  filled  by  the  poor  and  vulnerable,  including  unemployed  persons,  rural  migrants,  and 
women,  representing  therefore  a  key  intervention  in  the  poverty  cycle.  Project  operations  will 
create  220  full-time  permanent  jobs  with  the  WDC  and  an  additional  130  full-time  permanent 
jobs throughout the municipality. 
 
57. 
A participatory process has been used throughout project preparation. Methods included 
household  and  business  surveys,  consultation  with  key  stakeholders,  focus  group  discussions 
and public consultations, and key informant interviews with involved agencies. The participatory 
approach  will  continue  during  project  implementation,  monitoring,  and  evaluation,  and  will  be 
based  on  periodic  public  hearings  on  tariff  increases  and  a  new  customer  complaints  desk  to 
receive, process, and document customer complaints. A number of key indicators are proposed 
for monitoring the social and poverty reduction aspects of the Project. Most of these have been 
incorporated  into  the  design  and  monitoring  framework.  The  poverty  reduction  and  social 
strategy is summarized in Appendix 12. 
 
C. 
 
58. 
The financial evaluation of the Project was undertaken in real terms using constant 2005 
prices. The project cost estimates and financial projections in nominal terms were converted to 
real terms by adjusting for the projected effects of foreign and domestic inflation and currency 
fluctuation.  Incremental  benefits  and  costs  were  derived  by  evaluating  the  financial position  of 

Financial Aspects

the  IAs  under  with-  and  without-project  scenarios.  The  financial  internal  rate  of  return  for  the 
Project  was  computed  on  an  after-tax  basis  of  11.29%,  which  compares  favorably  with  the 
weighted average cost of capital in real terms of 3.0%. The financial analysis is in Appendix 13.  
 
The  sensitivity  analysis  includes  an  examination  of  the  risk  that  project  costs  will 
59. 
increase by 10%, or that revenues will decrease by 10%; the resulting financial internal rates of 
return  are  10.07%  and  8.82%,  respectively.  A  detailed  verification  of  the  local  financing  plan 
reveals  that  the  equity  contributions  from  WMG  are  less  than  1.5%  of  its  annual  revenue, 
indicating minimal risk. WMG has the financial resources to guarantee the loan repayments, and 
has provided assurances that it accepts this risk. An affordability analysis, based on proposed 
tariffs  and  household  income  data  from  the  social  survey,  has  been  undertaken.  Tariffs  under 
the  Project  are  considered  affordable  if  the  combined  average  water  and  wastewater  charges 
are less than 5% of household income. The estimated tariffs on this basis are affordable to the 
average household (2% of income), and also affordable to the poorest 10% of households (less 
than  3.3%  of  income  before  accounting  for  poverty  reduction  measures  that  exist  now  or  that 
have been committed to).  
 
60. 
The  IAs  have  agreed  to  minimum  levels  of  financial  performance,  and  these  will  be 
included as loan covenants covering capital structure (debt to equity), debt service cover, and 
liquidity.  Financial  projections  estimate  the  tariffs  required  for  an  appropriate  level  of  financial 
performance.  Periodic  tariff  reviews  will  be  required  to  overcome  the  risk  of  poor  financial 
performance  or  of  unexpected  changes  in  the  tariff  income.  The  Project  is  considered  both 
financially viable and sustainable.  
 
D. 
 
61. 
A thorough review of policy and planning documents and regulations was completed to 
verify  that  water  quality  standards  are  defensible  and  that  the  project  is  consistent  with  state, 
provincial,  and  municipal  pollution  control  and  water  management  plans  and  with  local 
infrastructure  development  policies  and  plans.  The  Project  is  an  integral  part  of  the  ongoing 
provincial,  municipal,  and  basin-wide  environmental  programs,  contributing  directly  to  the 
environmental protection of the YRB. Public perceptions and preferences were also evaluated 
using household and business surveys. The analysis demonstrated that, when compared with a 
range of other public services, stormwater and wastewater service improvements clearly ranked 
first in priority.  
 
A  quantitative  economic  analysis  also  demonstrated  the  value  of  the  Project.  The 
62. 
economic  analysis  was  conducted  over  a  25-year  period  inclusive  of  the  project  construction 
period,  in  accordance  with  ADB’s  Guidelines  for  the  Economic  Analysis  of  Projects.  Project 
benefits  and  costs  were  estimated  on  a  with-  and  without-project  basis  and  appropriately 
apportioned on the basis of being tradable or non-tradable, and appropriate adjustments were 
made for non-incremental and incremental project benefits. Incremental benefits were valued on 
the  basis  of  willingness  to  pay  and,  in  the  case  of  flood  prevention,  damages  avoided.  The 
economic  internal  rate  of  return  (EIRR)  for  the  wastewater  management  component  is  22.6% 
and  the  EIRR  for  the  stormwater  management  component  is  19.6%.  The  EIRR  for  the  whole 
Project is estimated at 21.5%, which exceeds the economic opportunity cost of capital, assumed 
at  12%.  The  economic  analysis  is  in  Appendix  14.  The  willingness  to  pay  technical  note  is  in

The Project will improve the urban environment and surface water quality in Wuhan and in the 
YRB.  It  will  target  substantial  improvements  in  wastewater  management  and  will  have 
significant  positive  effects  on  water  pollution  control  in  the  Wuhan  reach  of  the  YRB.  More 
reliable  potable  water  will  be  provided  to  Wuhan  residents,  as  a  result  of  improved  raw  water 
quality.  The  Project  will  have  an  overwhelmingly  positive  environmental  impact,  and  any 
environmental  risks  during  construction  and  the  life  of  the  Project  can  be  mitigated  through 
measures  in  the  SEIA.  The  annual  wastewater  to  be  treated  will  be  increased  by  about  77 
million tons to 215 million tons. In addition, the treatment of 102 million tons of wastewater will 
be  upgraded  from  primary  to  full  secondary  treatment.  Some  key  annual  wastewater  load 
reduction impacting the YRB is indicated in para. 47.  
 
The  cumulative  effects  of  these  wastewater  load  reductions  can  be  assessed  through 
64. 
comprehensive water quality modeling, which is being developed under the WWMP. Progress 
with the water quality modeling will be assessed at the time of the midterm review and will be 
further  developed  with  support  through  the  implementation  consultancy  services.  The 
environmental  management  plan,  prepared  as  part  of  the  SEIA,  will  guide  environmental 
mitigation and monitoring under the Project.  
 
F.

subprojects  under  the  Project  use  conventional  engineering  design  and  treatment  processes 
that are robust and with proven records of reliable performance. The equipment packages to be

WASTEWATER AND STORMWATER 
SECTOR/SUBSECTOR ANALYSIS 

Introduction 

Basin-Wide Focus 

 
A. 
 
1. 
An  important  strategy  in  the  Government’s  plan  to  control  and  reduce  pollution  is  to 
focus  on  basin-level  activities  especially  in  the  management  of  surface  water  quality.  The 
increase  in  the  quantities  of  municipal  and  industrial  wastewater  has  become  a  major 
contributor  to  pollution  in  rivers  and  lakes  in  the  People’s  Republic  of  China  (PRC).  Surface 
water and groundwater sources for urban water supply are frequently polluted to unacceptable 
levels.  Currently  only  about  40%  of  municipal  wastewater  (domestic  and  industrial)  is  treated 
before discharge into the receiving water bodies. The proportion of domestic wastewater is set 
to increase significantly as a result of increasing urbanization and improved efficiency in water 
use on the part of PRC industry. Government policy now requires that “cost recovery tariffs” be 
adopted  for  the  provision  of  wastewater  treatment.  In  contrast,  stormwater  drainage  is 
considered a non-revenue-generating activity, to be financed from local government revenues.  
 
B. 
 
2. 
The  focus  of  this  sector  analysis  will  be  at  the  basin  level.  The  Asian  Development 
Bank's  (ADB’s)  water  policy1 calls  for  ADB  to  support  integrated  water  resource  management, 
which in the present context means coordinated, basin-level activities to manage surface water 
quality.  A  “sectoral”  perspective  for  the  Project  must  relate  to  basin-wide  plans  for  managing 
surface  water  quality,  to  evaluate  the  implementation  of  the  plans,  and  to  assess  progress  in 
managing water quality. Wuhan is centrally located in the middle reaches of the Yangtze River 
basin (YRB), which is the largest river basin in the PRC and covers a large part of the country. 
The  Yangtze  River  is  about  6,380  kilometers  (km)  long  with  a  drainage  basin  of  1.2  million 
square  kilometer  (km2).  The  main  trunk  of  the  Yangtze  flows  in  an  easterly  direction  and 
eventually enters the East China Sea at Shanghai. Wuhan is also the headquarters of the YRB 
Commission (YRBC), which was set up by the central Government to manage water resources 
in the YRB.  
 
The  YRBC  has  prepared  and  gained  approval  for  the  Yangtze  River  water  resources 
3. 
protection plan (2002), which provides a broad framework for managing the water resources of 
the  YRB.  In  April  2005,  the  YRBC  sponsored  the  First  Yangtze  Forum  in  Wuhan.  The  forum 
issued a formal Yangtze Declaration on Protection and Development  (Declaration), which calls 
“…for active participation of all stakeholders in collaborative efforts to concurrently protect and 
develop  the  Yangtze  River  and  ensure  a  healthy  Yangtze  for  our  future  generations.”  The 
declaration highlights the importance of integrated river basin management.  
 
C. 
 
The  ADB  country  strategy  program  (CSP) 2 for  the  PRC  aims  to  promote  continued 
4. 
economic  growth  in  PRC  as  a  primary  means  of  reducing  poverty  in  the  country.  The  CSP 
recognizes,  however,  that  the  PRC’s  economic  growth  has  come  at  the  cost  of  serious 
environmental  degradation,  particularly  increased  air  and  water  pollution.  Environmental 
degradation  threatens  the  prospect  of  sustaining  the  PRC’s  economic  growth.  Improving 
environmental  protection  is  therefore  a  main  strategic  issue  and  one  of  the  main  thematic 
priorities of the CSP. A complementary objective and a main focus of the CSP is promoting the

provision  of  adequate  urban  infrastructure  to  improve  the  livelihood  of  the  rapidly  increasing 
urban population. The Project is fully consistent with ADB’s CSP, which calls for market-oriented 
reforms  and  attention  to  urban  environmental  problems.  The  market-oriented  reforms 
emphasized in the CSP include the principle of cost recovery through user charges, which is an 
important feature of the Project.  

 

Wuhan Urban Master Plan  

D. 
 
The Wuhan urban master plan 1996–2020 (WUMP) was approved by the State Council 
5. 
in  February  1999  and  is  the  mandatory  comprehensive  guide  for  all  aspects  of  municipal 
development  up  to  2020.  Local  planning  authorities  and  implementation  agencies  are  all 
required  to  follow  the  framework,  targets,  and  projections  set  out  in  the  plan,  which  includes 
planning for water supply, wastewater, and stormwater drainage management. In the context of 
the  current  Project,  it  is  useful  to  highlight  some  of  the  important  observations  made  by  the 
State Council: 
 

As  a  riverside  and  lakeside  city,  Wuhan  should  pay  more  attention  to  the  aquatic 
environmental  protection  and  rehabilitation,  so  as  to  develop  a  comprehensive 
wastewater  treatment  system  and  speed  up  wastewater  diversion  to  prevent  direct 
discharge  to  Yangtze  River  and  related  Lakes.  Before  2010,  urban  environmental 
pollution and ecological damages should have adequate control and urban environmental 
quality should have comprehensive improvement to ensure an ecological cycle by 2020. 
 
The urban master plan also states that Wuhan should: 

 
…assure  drinking  water  quality  in  both  the  Yangtze  and  the  Han  rivers,  implement 
comprehensive  water  quality  rehabilitation  and  protection  for  Donghu,  Shahu,  Nanhu, 
and  Mousui  Lakes;  assure  water  quality  in  the  Yangtze  and  Han  rivers  within  the  Main 
City section meets Class II national standards; and assure the water quality of the major 
lakes in the Main City meets Class III national standards. 

 
7. 
The plan highlights specific principles and targets that relate directly to controlling water 
pollution, increasing wastewater treatment, improving flood protection and stormwater systems, 
and  making  general  improvements  in  the  living  environment.  Some  of  the  more  important 
statements are summarized as follows: 
 

“Stormwater should be collected into different drainage systems and drained into 
the closest rivers or lakes; wastewater should be separated from stormwater and 
centrally  treated;  when  draining  the  stormwater,  both  urban  area  and  rural  area 
should be considered; gradually complete the urban drainage systems.”

protection areas. 
No discharges of untreated wastewater will be permitted in the urban reaches of 
the  Yangtze  and  Han  rivers,  and  water  quality  must  satisfy  Class  II  standards 
(GB 3838-96).

9. 
The standards and targets, especially for large urban areas like Wuhan, are set by the 
central  Government  (mainly  the  State  Council,  the  National  Development  and  Reform 
Commission,  the  State  Environmental  Protection  Administration  [SEPA],  the  Ministry  of 
Construction,  etc.)  and  provide  a  clear  framework  for  implementation  by  2010  and  2020.  The 
Wuhan municipal government (WMG) has adopted the standards and instructed the appropriate 
municipal agencies to plan, implement, and achieve the targets. In terms of drainage, Wuhan is 
located on the Hanjiang Plain with a surface elevation of 20–24 meters (m) (above sea level), 
which  is  below  the  average  floodwater  level  of  about  26  m.  During  the  rainy  season  (June  to 
September), sections of the municipality are served by a storm drainage network consisting of: 
(i) 1,482 km of drainage pipes and box culverts, (ii) 127 km of open channels, (iii) 69 pumping 
stations, and (iv) 47 sluice gates.  
 
In  the  main  urban  area,  the  drainage  network  density  is  about  7.2  km  per  km2.  The 
10. 
actual  drainage  network  is  a  mixed  system:  (i)  combined  collection  systems  (stormwater  and 
wastewater) serving the districts of Hankou, Hanyang, and Wuchang old town; and (ii) separate 
collection systems serving the Shuiguo Lake Region and Qingshan district, plus Zhuankou and 
Donghu  development  areas,  which  were  built  in  the  late  1990s.  The  main  problems  with 
Wuhan’s stormwater drainage system are: (i) continuing urbanization and new developments in 
the  limited  open  space  remaining  within  already  congested  areas;  (ii)  inadequate  network 
coverage; (ii) old infrastructure with poor and inadequate design standards; (iii) limitations of the 
combined  drainage  systems  leading  to  wastewater  overflows  during  storm  and  flood  events; 
and (iv) poor and inadequate maintenance of the drainage network.  
 
11.  Wuhan has been slow in developing adequate wastewater treatment facilities. The first 
wastewater  treatment  plant  (WWTP)  was  completed  in  1993  at  Shahu.  The  municipality  now 
has four operating WWTPs with a combined capacity of 530,000 cubic meters per day (m3/day) 
to primary and secondary treatment standards. The municipal authorities estimate that present 
WWTP capacity is only sufficient to cover 26.8% of total wastewater discharges, compared with 
an average of 41% for the main municipalities in the PRC. 
 
D. 

Overall Conclusions  

12.  Wuhan  Municipality  has  a  well-constructed  set  of  policies,  standards,  regulations,  and 
plans  for  the  wastewater  and  drainage  sector.  These  instruments  are  themselves  compatible 
with  national  PRC  policies  and  regulations.  The  relevant  Wuhan  sector  plans  are  compatible 
with the overall development plan for the city and are also compatible with the basin-wide YRB 
water resources protection plan prepared by the YRBC and approved by the State Council. The 
Project itself is part of the ongoing implementation of existing sector plans. 

  

Appendix 3

POLICY DIALOGUE 

Overall Policy Framework  

 
A. 
 
Discussions with the Wuhan project management office (WPMO) and relevant municipal 
1. 
agencies, and reference to specific national policy documents of the People’s Republic of China 
(PRC), reveal government policies in support of the Project and the establishment of institutional 
arrangements  for  project  sustainability.  These  policies  include:  (i)  corporatization,  instead  of 
direct government provision, of public services; (ii) Government’s role of enabler and regulator 
of services; (iii) separation between Government and enterprise management; (iv) financing of 
utility services from user charges, with tariffs set in accordance with cost recovery principles; (v) 
joint  billing  of  water  and  wastewater  charges  under  the  “one  bill,  two  items”  system; 
(vi) encouragement  of  appropriate  competition  and  private  sector  participation  (PSP)  for  both 
investment in infrastructure construction and also for operation and maintenance; (vii) adoption 
of the “polluter pays” principle; and (viii) promotion of social stability through poverty alleviation 
and equal opportunities. 

 
Reducing Trans-jurisdiction Pollution 

B. 
 
2. 
The Asian Development Bank (ADB) provided a $2.1 million cluster technical assistance 
(TA)  to  help  the  Government  strengthen  trans-jurisdiction  environment  management.  The  TA 
had  four  components:  (i)  legislation  for  the  prevention  and  control  of  trans-jurisdiction  water 
pollution;  (ii)  methods  and  procedures  for  the  management  of  trans-jurisdiction  water  quality; 
(iii) capacity building; and (iv) dissemination of the findings and recommendations for potential 
application  in  river  basins. 1  A  major  output  of  the  first  component  was  model  river  basin 
legislation developed for the Fen River in Shanxi Province, a major tributary of the Yellow River.  
 
C. 

Upstream and Basin-wide Pollution Prevention and Control 

3. 
In a densely populated province like Hubei, and generally within a major river basin like 
the  Yangtze  River  basin,  the  pollution  generated  by  one  city  can  cause  significant  harm 
downstream.  The  proposed  Project  responds  to  the  need  for  an  integrated  and  coordinated 
basin-wide  approach  to  investment  planning  and  environmental  management  for  best  results. 
The  policies  for  controlling  water  pollution  adopted  by  the  State  Environmental  Protection 
Administration  (SEPA)  clearly  identify  the  problems  of  cross-boundary  pollution,  and  the  need 
for  an  integrated  basin-wide  approach  to  water  pollution  management.  The  PRC  Water  Law, 
which  took  effect  in  2002,  emphasizes  the  need  to  adopt  a  basin-wide  approach  to  water 
resources  planning  and  strengthens  the  various  river  basin  organizations  that  prepare 
comprehensive  basin  plans.  The  PRC  Government  embraces  the  “polluter  pays”  concept  and 
places emphasis on the responsibilities of local governments to deal with pollution originating in 
their area of jurisdiction.  
 
D. 

Regulatory Enforcement and Monitoring for Environmental Management 

To build the capacity for sound environmental management and to strengthen the legal 
4. 
framework,  ADB  helped  to  train  the  staff  of  the  Environment  Protection  Commission,  and  is 
assisting the drafting and revision of some of the PRC’s environmental laws.2 ADB is helping to

the  PRC’s  transition  to  a  market  economy  and  its  adherence  to  international  environmental

in  environmental

environmental  protection  bureaus  (EPBs),  to  strengthen  environmental  standards  and  to 
enforce environmental laws and policies.4 
 
5. 
As  wastewater  treatment  plants  (WWTPs)  are  commissioned,  monitoring  and  control 
arrangements will need to be strengthened. In this connection, the Project supports (i) training in 
the operation and management of wastewater and stormwater facilities; (ii) further enhancement 
of  a  comprehensive  water  quality  model,  which  is  being  developed  under  the  ongoing  Wuhan 
Wastewater  Management  Project  (WWMP);  and  (iii)  monitoring  of  the  operation  and 
maintenance  of  the  wastewater  facilities  against  a  number  of  indicators,  as  part  of  the  design 
and monitoring framework.   
 
E. 

Wastewater Management 
 
6. 
The  focus  of  the  policy  dialogue  on  wastewater  management  is  the  integrated 
management  of  industrial  and  domestic  wastewater,  including  on-site  treatment  and  public 
sewer connections. WMG recognizes that adequate facilities must be provided for wastewater 
treatment,  to  safeguard  public  health.  ADB  has  supported  the  Government’s  wastewater 
management  policies  by  providing  several  loans  for  wastewater  treatment  components  in 
Beijing, Chaohu, Changchun, Chengde, Fuzhou, Hefei, Henan, Qingdao, Shanghai, Tangshan, 
Tianjin, Wuhan, and along the Hai River system.  
 
7. 
 At the national level the importance of wastewater treatment was also addressed under 
the  Urban  Environmental 
institutions 
responsible  for  environmental  improvement  in  a  number  of  cities,  and  identified  future 
infrastructure requirements. The national guidelines drafted under the Urban Wastewater Tariffs 
and Management Study6 made specific proposals in relation to the financing and management 
of  the  wastewater  sector.  These  ADB  projects  and  related  initiatives  provide  a  solid  basis  for 
ongoing policy dialogue in wastewater management.  
 
8. 
The  WMG  and  district-level  governments  have  prepared  wastewater  master  plans, 
including  the  use  of  sewers,  interceptors,  and  centralized  WWTPs  for  both  domestic  and 
industrial  wastewater.  These  plans  were  reviewed.  They  reflect  the  development  needs  of  the 
project area and the proposed components are consistent with those plans. 
 
F. 
 
13.      The  proposed  Project  will  significantly  increase  sludge  production  from  WWTPs  in  the 
Wuhan urban area. At present there is no government-endorsed strategy for the treatment and

G. 

Stormwater Management and Urban Drainage 
 
14. 
A  core  objective  of  the  proposed  Project  is  to  improve  stormwater  management  and 
urban drainage in areas of Wuhan that flood during storms. The frequent high-intensity storms 
during  the  summer  rainy  season,  quite  often  affect  areas  that  are  susceptible  to  flooding 
because  of  poor  drainage.  Where  there  are  combined  stormwater  and  wastewater  sewers, 
these  contain  foul  sewage,  creating  health  risks.  The  WMG  has  prepared  and  approved  a 
wastewater  master  plan  that  provides  for  the  progressive  separation  of  wastewater  sewerage 
and  stormwater  drainage.  Separating  wastewater  and  stormwater  will  help  lessen  the  health 
risks from urban flooding and help protect the WWTPs from hydraulic overloading. Stormwater 
management in Wuhan (and elsewhere in the PRC) is viewed as a public service that should be 
financed from government revenues. Alternative financing mechanisms like a user charge or a 
property tax or levy for storm water could be the subject of a future advisory TA from ADB.  
 
H. 

Cost Recovery and Tariff Reform 

The  Project  will  support  the  Government’s  ongoing  economic  and  enterprise  reform 
15. 
programs  that  require  all  water  supply  and  wastewater  management  projects  to  be  financially 
sustainable and capable of cost recovery. ADB’s key policy dialogue agenda is concerned with 
continued water and wastewater tariff reforms in the PRC. ADB funded two water tariff studies 
and  one  wastewater  tariff  study  in  support  of  the  Government’s  initiatives.  The  National 
Guidelines on Water Tariffs (NGWT) were prepared during the first water tariff study, and were 
promulgated  by  the  National  Development  and  Reform  Commission  and  the  Ministry  of 
Construction  in  September  1998.  The  NGWT  improved  the  long-term  financial  viability  of  the 
water  supply  companies  and  provided  for  operation  and  maintenance  and  service  expansion, 
which would also help increase PSP in the water and wastewater sector. The WMG confirmed 
the implementation of the NGWT. ADB’s wastewater tariff study  TA7 carried out between 2002 
and  2003,  on  the  other  hand,  contributed  to  wastewater  tariff  reform.  Circular  No.  1192  of 
September  1999,  amending  the  policy  guidance  on  wastewater  tariff  setting,  requires 
wastewater  tariffs  to  be  based  on  the  principle  of  cost  recovery  but  allows  local  governments 
flexibility in deciding when to implement the circular. The WMG has been increasing water and 
wastewater tariffs in keeping with the state policy. Stormwater management is, however, viewed 
as a non-revenue-generating activity in the PRC. 
 
16. 
The project financial analysis assumes that the tariff levels are based on the principle of 
cost  recovery  and  the  project  IAs  can  implement  and  collect  these  tariffs  adequately.  The 
analysis  shows  that  the  IAs  can  be  financially  autonomous  and  sustainable.  Wastewater 
charges levied in the main urban area of Wuhan (currently CNY0.80 per m3) are already higher 
than  those  in  other  cities  in  the  PRC.  The  WMG  plans  to  hold  a  public  hearing  in  the  fourth 
quarter of 2006 to discuss a projected increase to about CNY1.00 per m3 or CNY1.10 per m3 by 
2007.  
 
17. 
In  Wuhan,  the  local  water  supply  company  collects  wastewater  fees  through  the  “one 
bill, two items” approach, which has been shown in other countries to be the most effective way 
of  collecting  wastewater  charges.  Improved  public  awareness  of  the  benefits  of  effective
