Private Sector Participation 

wastewater  drainage  and  treatment  can  make  them  much  more  willing  to  pay  wastewater 
charges.  Socioeconomic  surveys  done  during  the  project  preparatory  TA  indicated  a 
significantly  greater  public  willingness  to  pay  than  in  most  other  PRC  cities.  This  is  a  very 
positive indicator of public support for the proposed project investments.  
 
I. 
 
18.  While  the  use  of  the  private  sector  as  a  source  of  both  finance  and  expertise  is  now 
largely  recognized  and  accepted  by  local  governments  in  the  PRC,  much  work  remains  to  be 
done to ensure adequate market regulation so that procurement is open and transparent, and 
the interests of investors, the Government, and customers are safeguarded. These aspects of 
PSP will require continuing policy dialogue and capacity-building initiatives at the national level. 
The  Project  will  create  the  enabling  environment  for  eventual  PSP  by  pursuing  tariff  reforms, 
cost recovery, enterprise reform, and better governance—all prerequisites for such involvement. 
Further,  during  project  implementation,  the  loan  consultants  will  assist  the  Executing  Agency 
(WMG) in preparing a strategy for PSP in the Wuhan wastewater sector, including a plan for the 
Wuhan Drainage Company (WDC) to seek listing on one of the regional stock exchanges. 
 
J.       Corporate Governance and Enterprise Reform 
 
The  progressive  transformation  of  the  WDC  into  a  financially  and  managerially 
19. 
autonomous  enterprise  creates  the  institutional  framework  for  project  implementation,  and  for 
sustainable operations in the medium to long term.  
 
20.  WDC  already  has  managerial  autonomy,  with  its  own  board  of  directors  and  well-
developed internal controls. The financial management assessment that was done revealed no 
significant  concerns  with  audit  arrangements  and  the  adopted  accounting  policies.  Financial 
management arrangements are being further strengthened under the capacity-building program 
of the ongoing WWMP. The WMG is progressively implementing central government policies to 
separate  government  from  direct  involvement  in  the  management  of  state-owned  enterprises 
while at the same time improving supervision.

  Appendix 7 

 
A. 

Introduction 

FINANCIAL MANAGEMENT ASSESSMENT 

FMA for the Wuhan Urban Drainage Development Company Limited 

1.        The  financial  management  skills  of  the  implementing  agencies  (IAs)—Wuhan  Drainage 
Company Limited (WDC) and Wuhan Urban Construction Foundation (WUCF)—were assessed 
with  the  use  of  the  Asian  Development  Bank  (ADB)  financial  management  assessment 
questionnaire.  The  financial  management  assessment  (FMA)  was  done  to  assess  the 
institutional  capacity,  funds  flow  arrangements,  staffing,  accounting  policies  and  procedures, 
internal and external auditing arrangements, reporting and monitoring aspects, and information 
systems of both IAs. Issues or risks associated with their financial management systems were 
identified,  and  appropriate  risk  mitigation  measures  proposed  to  improve  project  design  and 
implementation. 
 
B. 
 
Background.  The  WDC  was  established  on  6  September  1995  with  registered  capital 
2. 
of  CNY48.5  million  as  a  fully  state-owned  company.  It  is  also  the  IA  for  the  ongoing  ADB-
financed Wuhan Wastewater Management Project. The  Wuhan  municipal  government  (WMG) 
and  the  Wuhan  project  management  office  (WPMO)  are  also  experienced  in  preparing  and 
implementing  major  projects  funded  by  ADB,  the  World  Bank,  and  bilateral  agencies  from 
Finland and Poland. For ADB-financed projects, the IA staffs are trained in ADB loan processing 
policies  and  in  procurement  arrangement  and  disbursement  procedures.  The  training  is 
organized  by  the  Government  and  ADB.  This  experience  should  facilitate  the  smooth  and 
successful implementation of the proposed Project. 
 
3. 
PRC’s  Accounting  Standards  and  Auditing  Standards.  Through its new accounting 
and  auditing  standards,  the  PRC  seeks  to  conform  to  international  standards  and  practices 
while  taking  into  account  the  special  conditions  in  the  PRC.  These  new  national  accounting 
standards must be consistently followed to ensure the accurate and timely interpretation of the 
financial  position  and  performance  of  the  IA,  and  the  proper  use  of  the  project  expenditures 
according  to  the  loan  agreement  while  taking  economy  and  efficiency  into  account.  Certified 
public accountants (CPAs) in the PRC carry out general-purpose audits to give their opinion as 
to whether the financial statements are presented fairly in all material respects, according to the 
PRC’s  accounting  standards  and  other  regulations,  and  consistently  with  the  preceding  year’s 
statements.  
 
4. 
Audit. The project preparatory technical assistance (TA) included a review of the audit 
reports  and  audited  financial  statements  of  WDC  for  2002,  2003,  and  2004,  audited  by  the 
Wuhan Municipal Audit Bureau. The CPAs had issued a qualified opinion on the 2003 financial 
statements,  and  an  unqualified  opinion  on  the  2004  financial  statements.  The  WDC  indicated 
that it had accepted and implemented all suggestions and required adjustments suggested by 
the  CPAs.  WDC  has  experienced  internal  auditors,  reporting  directly  to  the  WDC  board  of 
directors,  to  audit  its  subsidiaries  and  branches.  The  current  WDC  audit  arrangements, 
including  internal  audit,  external  government  audit,  and  CPA  audit,  satisfy  ADB’s  audit 
requirements.  Overall,  the  audited  financial  statements  appeared  to  be  of  good  quality  with 
detailed notes to the statements. The internal control system is adequate. 
 
Conclusion.  The  overall  financial  management  arrangements  of  the  WDC  are 
5. 
satisfactory  and  reliable.  ADB’s  financial  due-diligence  requirements,  especially  the  audit  and 
reporting  requirements  normally  mentioned  in  the  ADB  memorandum  of  understanding  and

FMA for the Wuhan Urban Construction Foundation

loan fact-finding mission.  
 
C. 
 
6. 
Background.  The  WUCF  is  an  independent  legal  entity  supervised  by  the  WMG.  It 
finances and implements public sector construction projects that can not be implemented on a 
commercial basis. WUCF, which will be the IA for the stormwater component, is experienced in 
preparing  and  implementing  World  Bank–financed  projects,  particularly  the  Wuhan  Urban 
Transportation Project. This experience will facilitate the smooth and successful implementation 
of the proposed Project. 
 
Financial  Management  Assessment.  The  WUCF  has  adopted  the  accrual  basis  of 
7. 
accounting,  and  follows  the  PRC  accounting  systems  for  institutional  entities  and  state-owned 
construction enterprises. These are generally adequate for project accounting. The WUCF also 
has adequate internal control systems. The financial management system is computerized and 
can  produce  the  necessary  project  financial  reports.  Qualified  internal  auditors  report  to  the 
WUCF  director  general.  The  WUCF  financial  statements  are  subject  to  audit,  and  the 
stormwater  subproject  accounts  in  particular  must  be  audited  by  the  Wuhan  Municipal  Audit 
Bureau. The overall audit arrangements, including internal audit, external government audit, and 
CPA audit, meet ADB’s audit requirements.  
 
8. 
The  financial  department  of  WUCF  is  adequately  staffed.  WUCF  has  indicated  that  it 
would  assign  a  qualified  officer-in-charge,  an  accountant,  and  a  cashier  to  the  ADB-financed 
project,  and  maintain  special  project  accounts  for  the  stormwater  component.  Training  for 
WUCF  in  ADB  loan  processing  policies  and  in  procurement  arrangement  and  disbursement 
procedures, among others, is planned under the proposed Project.  
 
9. 
policies and related procedures for procurement and disbursement, among others. 
 

Conclusion.  The  WUCF  staff  concerned  should  be  trained  in  ADB  loan  processing

  Appendix 8 

PROJECT SUSTAINABILITY 
 

Introduction 

A. 
 
The sustainability of project assets and the benefits derived from them is a key indicator 
1. 
of project success. The sustainability of the proposed Project will depend on the viability of the 
operating  authorities  for  the  wastewater  and  stormwater  components  and  the  quality  of  their 
project construction, maintenance, and repair efforts. 

 
Wuhan Drainage Company 

B. 
 
2. 
The Wuhan Drainage Company Limited (WDC) is the implementing agency (IA) for the 
four wastewater components of the Project. It will manage both the construction and operation 
of  these  components.  WDC  is  a  properly  constituted  enterprise  company  established  under 
People’s Republic of China (PRC) law, and largely has managerial and financial autonomy.  
 
WDC was established in 1995–1996 as a wastewater construction company to serve as 
3. 
the project management office for the Wuhan wastewater component of the World Bank–funded 
Hubei Urban Environment Project. This project and a later World Bank technical assistance to 
WDC promoted institutional reforms, which led to the drafting of an institutional action plan that 
was accepted by WDC management and the World Bank in 1999. The WDC has made steady 
progress since then. It now has a board of directors, a valid business license, and a company 
charter. Following the transfer of the Shahu wastewater treatment plant (WWTP) to the WDC in 
1999,  WDC  assumed  responsibility  for  operating  the  trunk  sewerage  system  and  six  pumping 
stations  in  the  contributing  service  area  in  the  autumn  of  2001.  In  2002  all  wastewater  assets 
were  transferred  to  the  WDC  from  various  government  agencies.  Since  2003,  all  wastewater 
tariff revenues have been transferred to WDC and are now managed by the company.  
 
Project Construction Management Capacity. Besides its experience with World Bank 
4. 
projects, the WDC is also the IA for the ongoing ADB Wuhan Wastewater Management Project 
(WWMP).  Its  proven  implementation  capacity  provides  a  high  level  of  assurance  of  project 
success. The WDC has committed to assign qualified finance and accounts staff to the Project 
for effective control, management, and reporting. In addition, project budgets include a provision 
for project audit—an unusual but very encouraging feature of the Project. 
 
5. 
Operational  Management  Capacity.  WDC  owns  the  assets,  administers  operational 
budgets,  and  has  established  an  operations  unit  to  supervise  and  coordinate  the  operational 
activities performed.  
 
6. 
Financial  Management  Capacity. Overall, the financial management arrangements of 
WDC are satisfactory and can be relied on to support effective decision making. Key features of 
the  current  arrangements  are:  (i)  use  of  an  accrual  basis  of  accounting  and  adherence  to 
relevant  national  accounting  standards,  (ii)  adequate  internal  controls,  (iii)  adequately  trained 
and  qualified  staff,  (iv)  computerized  accounting  records  with  the  capacity  to  produce  the 
necessary project financial reports, and (v) internal auditors to audit subsidiaries and branches 
of  the  WDC.  Internal  auditors  report  directly  to  the  board  of  directors.  Current  WDC  audit 
arrangements, including internal audit, external government audit, and audit by certified public 
accountants  (CPAs),  meet  ADB’s  audit  requirements.  Audited  financial  statements  for  fiscal 
years 2002, 2003, and 2004 are generally of good quality, and provide detailed notes to allow 
users to gain a reasonable understanding of the WDC’s financial performance. 
 

  

Appendix 8 

39 

Wuhan Urban Construction Foundation 

Capacity-Building  Support  to  WDC. WDC has received capacity-building assistance, 
7. 
including  institutional  and  financial  management  strengthening,  under  the  World  Bank–funded 
Hubei  Urban  Environment  Project  and  ADB’s  ongoing  WWMP.  In  the  WWMP,    WDC  is 
improving  its  oversight  and  control  of  operations  through  capacity  building  and  ADB’s  own 
supervision  of  the  project.  WDC  is  competent  in  project  implementation  but  will  benefit  from 
assistance  in  certain  aspects  of  wastewater  operations,  such  as  the  management  of  sewer 
connections, detection and prevention of water inflow and infiltration into wastewater collectors, 
and sludge management.  
 
8. 
Future  Financial  Performance  of  WDC.  Consolidated  pro  forma  financial  statements 
for  WDC  are  given  in  Supplementary  Appendix  N.  These  are  based  on  proposed  plans  for 
wastewater  tariff  adjustments  and  indicate  a  satisfactory  financial  performance.  The  cost 
recovery ratio exceeds 1.0 throughout the projection period and a debt service coverage ratio of 
1.3  can  be  reached  by  2013.  The  return  on  equity  following  project  commissioning  averages 
6.2% (2010 to 2018) and varies between 4.3 and 7.5%. These are satisfactory results.  
 
C. 
 
9. 
The  Wuhan  Urban  Construction  Foundation  (WUCF)  is  the  IA  for  the  stormwater 
component of the Project. WUCF is a government agency that finances and implements public 
sector  construction  projects  that  are  not  commercially  viable.  WUCF  will  also  undertake  debt 
servicing and repayment for the stormwater component. Operations are funded out of general 
government revenues. 
 
The  policy  of  separating  wastewater  and  stormwater  sewers,  together  with  recent 
10. 
institutional reforms, has led to a division of responsibilities for the management and operation 
of  the  separated  networks.  The  stormwater  network  is  now  managed  overall  by  the  Wuhan 
Municipal Water Authority, with most operations performed at a local level by district-level  units 
under district water bureaus. 
 
11. 
Construction  Project  Management  Capacity.  The  WUCF’s  previous  experience  in 
implementing  the  World  Bank–financed  Wuhan  Urban  Transportation  Project  will  facilitate  the 
successful implementation of the proposed Project. WUCF has engaged a project construction 
management  company,  Jianxing  Company,  to  assist  with  project  construction.  Jianxing 
Company  is  licensed  to  undertake  urban  infrastructure  work  and  is  experienced  in  similar 
projects.  
 
12. 
Operational Management Capacity. WUCF will not be involved in future operation and 
maintenance.  The  new  assets,  once  commissioned,  will  be  handed  over  to  the  district  water 
bureaus  and  managed  by  the  Wuhan  Municipal  Water  Authority.  In  all,  about  2,000  staff 
members  of  these  agencies  operate  and  maintain  the  stormwater  drainage  and  pumping 
facilities in the urban areas of the city. 
 
13. 
Financial  Management  Capacity. Overall, the financial management arrangements of 
WUCF  are  satisfactory  and  can  be  relied  on  to  support  effective  project  management.  Key 
features  of  the  current  arrangements  are:  (i)  use  of  an  accrual  basis  of  accounting  and 
adherence  to  relevant  national  accounting  standards,  (ii)  use  of  appropriate  internal  controls, 
(iii)   adequately  trained  and  qualified  staff,  (iv)  use  of  computerized  accounting  records,  and 
(v) use  of  internal  auditors  reporting  to  the  director  general  of  the  WUCF.  Current  audit 
arrangements, including internal audit, external government audit, and CPA audit, meet ADB’s 
audit requirements. WUCF staff will be trained in ADB loan processing policies and procedures. 

 

 40 

  Appendix 8 

Risks and Risk Mitigation 

 
14. 
Capacity-Building  Support  to  WUCF.  The  proposed  capacity-building  initiatives  for 
stormwater  services  under  the  proposed  Project  will  focus  on:  (i)  training  for  WUCF  and 
Jianxing Company staff in relevant ADB project funding procedures; (ii) review of organizational 
structure,  operations,  and  maintenance  to  identify  ways  to  improve  efficiency;  and  (iii) 
identification  of  opportunities  for  market  reform  and  private  sector  participation  (PSP),  and 
training of government staff in PSP procurement and regulation. 
 
Future  Financial  Performance.  WUCF  is  a  non-revenue-generating  entity.  Currently 
15. 
there  is  no  legal  provision  in  the  PRC  for  levying  a  user  charge  for  stormwater  drainage.  The 
service is funded from the local government budget. Annual operating and maintenance costs 
for  the  Project  are  much  less  than  1%  of  government  revenues.  Funding  has  therefore  been 
generally  adequate  and  should  continue  to  be  adequate  to  assure  sustainable  benefits  from 
project improvements.  
 
D. 
 
16. 
Financial risks arise primarily from the need for counterpart funding for construction, and 
for tariff increases to ensure cost recovery. These risks are mitigated by assurances related to 
funding  and  tariff  increases.  The  Government’s  participatory  processes  for  tariff  adjustment 
serve  to  further  mitigate  the  risk  that  tariffs  will  not  be  increased.  Consulting  services  and 
training represent a general mitigation measure to counter the risk of resistance to institutional 
reforms such as increased PSP and the consolidation of fragmented roles and responsibilities in 
both stormwater and wastewater operations.  
 
E. 
 
17. 
The assessment of sustainability covers both the construction and operational phases of 
the  Project  and  considers  financial  and  managerial  capabilities.  In  light  of  the  resources  and 
experience of the implementing agencies and the arrangements planned for project construction 
and operation, the Project is considered likely to be sustainable. Certain deficiencies and risks 
have been identified and mitigation measures for these are in place or are proposed in the form 
of  project  assurances  and  provisions  for  capacity  building.  The  tariff  reforms  undertaken  by 
WMG,  including  the  generation  of  project  construction  funds  ($28.4  million)  directly  from 
wastewater tariffs, will contribute significantly to project sustainability. Further, WMG has issued 
a policy statement indicating that wastewater tariffs will be introduced in Caidian and increased 
in Dongxihu, both suburban areas, in 2006. This demonstrates that WMG is highly progressive 
in adopting tariff reforms. 
 

Conclusion

SUMMARY RESETTLEMENT PLAN 
 

Background 

A. 
 
The Project is composed of a wastewater component and a stormwater component. The 
1. 
wastewater  component  has  five  subprojects—in  the  urban  area,  Erlangmiao  wastewater 
treatment plant (WWTP) expansion and upgrade, Nantaizi Lake WWTP expansion and sewage 
collection  system,  and  Huangpu  road  WWTP  upgrade;  and  in  the  suburban  area,  Caidian 
WWTP  and  sewage  collection  system  and  Dongxihu  wastewater  collection  system.  The 
stormwater  component  has  four  subprojects—Yangsigang  drainage  pumping  station  and  its 
associated stormwater network, Dongxihu three-drainage-gate connection, Changqing pumping 
station  expansion,  and  Luojia  road  drainage  pumping  station  and  rehabilitation  of  Luojiagang 
open  channel.  For  the  Erlangmiao  WWTP  and  Huangpu  road  WWTP  subprojects  in  the 
wastewater component, land was acquired and set aside in 1998 (for Erlangmiao) and 1999 (for 
Huangpu  road)  during  the  first  phase  of  construction.  The  affected  persons  have  been 
compensated  and  relocated  with  a  satisfactory  outcome.  The  land  provided  is  enough  for  the 
later  expansion  or  upgrading  of  these  two  facilities.  Therefore,  no  more  land  needs  to  be 
acquired for these two subprojects under the Project.  
 
2. 
The rest of the works will, however, involve a relatively large amount of land acquisition 
and  resettlement.  Two  full  resettlement  plans  (RPs)  based  on  ADB  procedures  have  already 
been prepared. The cutoff date for eligibility for compensation and assistance under the Project 
will be the date the Hubei Development and Reform Commission approves the RPs. That date 
will be announced to all affected persons as soon as possible. Once the detailed engineering of 
each subproject is finalized, the resettlement plans will be amended if necessary to reflect any 
design changes. 
 
B. 
 
3. 
Local officials, village or street committees, and affected persons were closely consulted 
during the feasibility study and preliminary design stages in the effort to avoid or minimize land 
acquisition and resettlement, and the best site among the alternatives was recommended. 
 
4. 
The proposed Project will affect 4 districts, 15 villages, and 1 neighborhood in Hanyang, 
Dongxihu,  Hongshan,  and  Caidian  districts  of  Wuhan  city.  In  all,  421  households  with  1,799 
persons (including 538 persons classified as floating population) will be affected directly by land 
acquisition or house demolition, and 938.3 mu of land, of which 59.4% is classified as cultivated 
land,  will  be  permanently  occupied.  In  addition,  390.7  mu  of  land  will  be  occupied  temporarily 
during  the  construction  phase,  and  the  following  will  be  demolished:  39,288  m2  of  residential 
housing  (4,157  m2  of  which  is  unlicensed  housing),  comprising  34,638  m2  (88.2%)  of  rural 
housing  and  4,650  m2  (11.8%)  of  urban  housing;  43  enterprises  and  institutions  with 
18,881.85 m2  of  structures;  and  19  shops  with  10,912  m2  of  structures  (4,070  m2  of  these 
unlicensed). The details are tabulated in Table A11.1.

Policy and Legal Framework 

C. 
 
5. 
For people who will be unavoidably affected by the Project, the resettlement objective is 
to achieve equal, or better, income and living standards, in line with PRC laws and regulations, 
as well as ADB’s policy on involuntary resettlement.1 The compensation for permanent land loss 
and  house  demolition  is  based  on  the  Land  Administration  Law  of  PRC  (2004),  the  State 
Council  Decision  to  Deepen  Reform  and  Strictly  Enforce  Land  Administration  (Document  28 
dated  November  2004),  and 
the  Land  Administration 
Administrative Law of Hubei Province (2nd revision) (effective 27 September 1999), as follows: 
Method of Collective Land Acquisition and Compensation for Housing Demolition on Collective 
Land of Wuhan Municipality (Wuhan Government Decree No. 148, effective 1 February 2004) 
and  Management  and  Implementation  Method  of  Urban  Housing  Demolition  of  Wuhan 
Municipality (Wuhan Government Decree  No. 130, effective 1 March 2002). 
 
6. 
After  consulting  local  governments  and  affected  persons,  the  project  implementing 
agencies  (IAs)  adopted  a  set  of  compensation  standards  based  on  the  replacement  cost  and 
general  practice  in  the  project  districts.  The  resettlement  principles  established  for  the  Project 
are:  (i)  wherever  feasible,  land  acquisition  and  involuntary  resettlement  will  be  avoided  or 
minimized through the development of design alternatives and the choice of the best alternative; 
(ii) compensation and entitlements provided will be based on market value or replacement value 
and must be adequate to allow those affected to at least maintain or, better yet, improve their 
pre-project standard of living; (iii) temporary land occupancy and the period of disruption are to 
be kept to a minimum; (iv) all the people affected, whether legal or illegal residents, are to be 
taken into consideration and accounted for; (v) the per capita landholding after land acquisition 
will be enough to maintain the previous livelihood standards; (vi) where the land allocation per 
capita  is  not  enough  to  maintain  the  previous  livelihood  standards,  other  income-generating 
activities  will  be  provided  for;  (vii)  vulnerable  groups  and  the  floating  population  will  be  given 
preference  in  such  matters  as  compensation,  housing  assignment,  transfer,  and  employment; 
(viii)  all  those  affected  will  be  adequately  informed  about  eligibility,  compensation  rates  and 
standards, livelihood and income restoration plans, and project timing; and (ix) close monitoring 
and timely actions will be carried out to identify and resolve problems as they arise.  

 

Land  acquisition  compensation  and  resettlement  subsidy  will  be  paid  to  the  affected 
7. 
village  committee.  Compensation  for  young  crops,  auxiliaries,  and  other  assets  will  be  paid 
directly  to  affected  farmers.  Compensation  for  the  loss  of  residential  housing,  enterprises, 
institutions, and shops will be paid directly to the owners and will be based on the agreements 
signed  with  them  as  provided  in  the  component  RPs.  The  payments  will  be  made  in  cash 
according to the appraised value of the property. Cash compensation will be given for income 
losses resulting from reductions in production, sales, or wages caused by the Project.  
 
D. 
 
8. 
To  minimize  the  resettlement  impact  on  affected  persons  (APs)  and  restore  their  living 
standards, detailed programs of restoration and relocation have been included in the RPs. APs 
can choose the program that suits their requirements. 
 
9. 
Different  schemes  for  income  restoration  will be  carried  out  according  to  the  economic 
characteristics of the affected villages. As to land acquisition, the most affected villages in the 
suburban or urban areas of Wuhan can be defined as “villages in a city.” Households are only 

Resettlement and Rehabilitation  

                                                 
1 ADB. 1998. The Bank’s Policy on Involuntary Resettlement. Manila. 

 

 48 

         Appendix 11 

partially  engaged  in  agricultural  activities,  and  family  members  supplement  their  incomes 
through outwork or other activities that often contribute the greater portion of their income. The 
main  income  restoration  strategies  and  measures  are  cash  compensation,  commercial  land 
investment and development, provision of employment opportunities during project construction 
and  operation,  and  provision  of  training  and  employment  information.  Contracts  will  be  signed 
with the village committee and APs to confirm the APs’ acceptance of the use of funds and the 
proposals. Through these measures, the APs should earn stable incomes that fully restore their 
living standards. 
 
10. 
Compensation for housing and other structures demolished will be at replacement cost. 
Displaced persons will have the option to purchase commercial houses, exchange properties, or 
rebuild their houses on house sites provided to them without charge.  
 
11. 
In  addition,  more  attention  will  be  paid  to  the  compensation  and  rehabilitation  of 
vulnerable groups. These groups will receive additional assistance from the Project as follows: 
(i) for demolished houses of 20 m2 or less, compensation or relocation will be the same as for 
houses  of  25  m2;  and  for  demolished  houses  larger  than  20  m2  but  less  than  30  m2, 
compensation or relocation will be the same as for houses of 30 m2; (ii) low-rental housing for 
vulnerable  families  will  be  provided;  (iii)  special  support  funds  (CNY1.9  million)  will  be  set  up; 
(iv) employment  opportunities  will  be  provided  to  seriously  affected  vulnerable  groups, 
especially  women;  and  (v) vulnerable  groups  will  be  given  labor  support  in  rebuilding  their 
houses. 
 

Resettlement Cost and Fund Management  

Information Disclosure, Participation, and Grievance Procedures 

E. 
 
12. 
Land acquisition and resettlement are estimated to total CNY355 million ($43.8 million, 
17.1% of the project cost), including contingencies, taxes, and duties. This land acquisition and 
resettlement cost will be part of the project cost. The RPs for the two project components each 
contain  a  detailed  budget  and  a  compensation  matrix.  Compensation  funds  will  be  paid  and 
used  according  to  the  compensation  policies  and  standards  defined  in  the  RPs,  under  the 
supervision  of  the  internal  monitoring  agencies  and  regular  review  by  the  external  monitoring 
agency.  Detailed  measurement  surveys  will  be  conducted  in  each  affected  village,  enterprise, 
and  shop,  and  the  compensation  contracts  will  be  negotiated  and  signed  with  the  village 
committees, households, enterprises, and shop owners. 
 
F. 
 
13.

A.

Analysis? 
Contribution of the sector/subsector to reducing poverty in the People’s Republic of China (PRC): 
By  2002,  the  PRC  had  performed  well  against  most  of  the  Millennium  Development  Goals 
(MDGs). Nonetheless, progress toward some goals and targets has been slow. This is the case 
with respect to improving the proportion of the population with access to safe drinking water and 
reversing  environmental  degradation.  The  Project  will  support  the  achievement  of  the  MDG  for 
environmental  sustainability  (MDG  7),  to  halve  the  proportion  of  people  without  sustainable 
access to safe drinking water and basic sanitation by 2015 (MDG target 10). 
 
The Project will provide new and improved wastewater and stormwater management services in 
Wuhan  Municipality.  Project  activities  will  reduce  the  contamination  of  local  water  bodies  and 
downstream  reaches  of  the  Yangtze  River  by  improving  the  collection  and  treatment  of 
wastewater.  Improvements  in  stormwater  management  will  reduce  local  flooding  and  the 
discharge  of  untreated  wastewater  into  surface  waters.  Other  benefits  include  the  protection  of 
public  health  and  reduction  in  economic  losses  due  to  flooding  and  water-related  disease.  In 
summary, the Project will reduce flooding and associated damages, provide more sanitary living 
conditions, alleviate environmental pollution, reduce morbidity and mortality from waterborne and 
water-washed  diseases,  and  reduce  the  associated  medical  costs  and  working  days  lost.  The 
poor will benefit disproportionately from the project improvements since they are more exposed 
to flooding, health, and other impairments and do not have the income or other resources to cope 
with them. They will also incur less financial loss from flood damage and health-care costs. 
 
Direct beneficiaries living within the project service areas number 3.0 million, of which 1.4 million 
will  realize  benefits  from  improved  wastewater  management,  1.5  million  from  improved 
stormwater  management,  and  0.1  million  from  both.  Indirect  beneficiaries  include  2.3  million 
persons  living  outside  the  project  service  areas  but  within  the  built-up  area  of  the  municipality, 
and 1.7 million persons living in riparian communities downstream of Wuhan. Direct beneficiaries 
include 0.26 million poor persons (those earning less than the official poverty line of CNY210 a 
month). Improved stormwater and wastewater management will improve the quality of life of poor 
and vulnerable people by reducing their risk of waterborne disease and associated expenditures 
on  medical  treatment.  The  number  of  school  days  and  workdays  lost  because  of  flooding  and 
sickness will be reduced. The Project will thus be a key intervention in the poverty cycle.  

Health  impact  was  analyzed  during  the  feasibility  study.  An  order-of-magnitude  analysis  of  the 
impact  on  morbidity  and  mortality  indicates  that  the  Project  may  reduce  the  incidence  of 
waterborne  diseases  by  an  average  of  8,000  cases  per  year.  Most  of  these  cases  will  not  be 
serious  enough  to  result  in  a  medical  consultation  or  reporting  under  government  disease 
surveillance  programs.  The  reduced  incidence  of  disease  is  associated  with  a  reduction  in 
workdays  lost,  by  5,800  days  yearly.  The  net  present  value  of  savings  in  medical  costs  and 
avoidance of lost earnings is CNY7.7 million (12%, from 2010 to 2040). 

The Project will provide 5,000 person-years of work over the 5-year construction period. Project-
related services, such as the procurement of construction materials and equipment and follow-on 
multiplier  effects  throughout  the  regional  economy,  are  expected  to  create  an  additional  9,000 
person-years  of  work.  Wuhan  Drainage  Company  officials  estimate  that  about  40%  of  the 
construction  jobs  will  be  filled  by  the  poor  and  vulnerable,  including  unemployed  persons,  rural 

 

         Appendix 12                53 

migrants, and women. Since unemployment is a major cause of poverty in the project area, the 
poor  will  benefit  disproportionately  from  this  job  creation.  Those  temporarily  employed  in 
construction  will  benefit  from  additional  training  and  experience,  which  will  provide  them  with 
opportunities  in  other  infrastructure  projects.  Project  operations  will  create  220  full-time 
permanent jobs. While these are primarily skilled jobs in water supply and wastewater treatment 
operations,  they  will  require  on-the-job  training  and  will  therefore  be  available  to  unemployed 
workers who have basic technical training and experience from their previous work in bankrupt 
state-owned  enterprises.  Multiplier effects  will lead  to  the  creation  of  an  additional  130  full-time 
permanent jobs throughout the municipality. 
B. 
Poverty Analysis                                  Proposed Classification: Targeted Intervention
The project is classified as targeted intervention because it contributes to achieving Millennium 
Development Goal 7, target 10, which calls for halving, by 2015, the proportion of people without 
access  to  safe  drinking  water  and  improved  sanitation.  The  poverty  analysis  is  based  on 
published statistical data from a socioeconomic survey done by ADB  of 500 households in the 
eight project areas of Wuhan in August 2005. A summary of the analysis and data is provided in 
the  project  preparatory  technical  assistance  (TA)  report.  Focus  group  discussions  and  in-depth 
interviews  with  key  informants  on  the  qualitative  aspect  of  poverty  supplemented  the 
socioeconomic survey and showed the multidimensionality of poverty. 
 
The  official  urban  poverty  line  used  by  Wuhan  Municipality  in  the  Minimum  Living  Security 
Scheme  (MLSS)  is  CNY210  per  capita  per  month,  as  noted  above.  In  2000,  the  incidence  of 
urban poverty including the floating population, based on this threshold, was 8%. Summary data 
on  household  income  and  expenditures  are  presented  in  Chapter  6  of  the  TA  report.  Poor 
households  in  the  project  area  share  many  of  the  characteristics  of  the  lowest-income 
households  profiled  in  the  ADB  report:  (i)  the  household  is  headed  by  a  long-laid-off  former 
employee of a state-owned enterprise, often with children of school age, or by a female; (ii) the 
household is made up of elderly people living alone; or (iii) the household members belong to the 
floating population. The poorest households have, on average, the greatest number of persons 
per household, the lowest number of persons with income, the highest number of income earners 
relying on the informal economy for their income, and the highest dependency ratio. Generally, 
the lowest-income households do not own the assets required to meet the basic needs for toilet, 
washing,  and  food  storage.  Vulnerable  households  lack  income-generating  ability  and  social 
support systems and are less able to cope with social and economic change.  
 
C. 

Participation Process 

Stakeholder  Analysis.  Stakeholder  analysis  was  conducted  throughout  project  preparation 
through  public  participation  and  consultation  with  key  stakeholders  such  as  government 
agencies,  beneficiaries,  project-affected  persons,  the  business  community,  and  civil  society 
organizations. In addition to the socioeconomic survey of households, focus group discussions, 
public  consultations,  and  interview  surveys  were  held,  with  306  affected  persons  participating. 
Key  informant  interviews  were  also  conducted  with  representatives  of  all  involved  government 
bureaus and the Women’s League. Issues related to the qualitative aspects of poverty, gender, 
affordability and willingness to pay, project impacts, and health status were discussed.  
 
Two  rounds  of  public  consultations  in  the  project  areas  were  carried  out  to  prepare  for  the 
environmental impact assessment (EIA) and the resettlement plan (RP). The public consultations 
and  disclosure  (i)  introduced  the  project  components  to  the  stakeholders;  (ii)  solicited  ideas, 
suggestions,  comments,  concerns,  and  critiques  on  the  potential  environmental implications 
of  the  Project;  and   (iii)  presented  the  findings  of  the  EIA  and  RP,  summarizing  potential 
 

 

 54         Appendix 12 

environmental  impacts  and  mitigation  measures,  and,  in  the  second  round,  providing  answers 
raised by workshop participants in the first round.  
 
Participation Strategy. The participatory approach is part of the project design and will be used 
during  project  implementation,  monitoring,  and  evaluation.  Public  consultations  will  be  held 
during project implementation to discuss and get feedback on tariff adjustments and affordability 
from consumers and other key stakeholders, particularly the poor. Existing participatory policies 
that  rely  on  public  hearings  to  gain  approval  for  tariff  adjustments  provide  the  mechanism  for 
these  consultations.  In  addition,  the  Wuhan  Drainage  Company  has  committed  to  establish  a 
customer  complaints  desk  to  receive,  process,  and  document  customer  complaints.  Public 
consultations  and  disclosure  of  resettlement  plans  were  conducted  during  surveys,  community 
meetings, interviews, and workshops. The results of these meetings and concerns of the affected 
persons  (APs),  particularly  the  poor  and  women  have  been  integrated  into  the  resettlement 
plans,  which  also  describe 
the  public  consultation  plan  and  grievance  process.  The 
consultations,  including  a  grievance  mechanism,  will  continue  during  land  acquisition  and 
resettlement so that the problems and needs of APs are properly addressed in a timely manner, 
before project implementation. 
 
D.  

Gender Development 

Strategy  to  Maximize  Impact  on  Women:  Stormwater  and  wastewater  service  deficiencies 
contribute to gender inequities in income-generating opportunities and burden of work. Data from 
the household survey indicate that women are primarily responsible for cleaning up after floods 
and  caring  for  the  sick.  Time  and  effort  spent  on  these  activities  means  less  time  for  income-
generating activities or family or rest. Improvements in stormwater and wastewater services will 
reduce this burden on women. To maximize the project benefits, women will be given priority in 
the employment opportunities generated by the Project, and women’s needs and interests will be 
represented  (50%  representation)  through  membership  on  customer  committees  of  the  Wuhan 
Drainage Company.

Project. As proposed, funding will come from an ADB loan (38%), local commercial bank loans 
(35%),  and  capital  contributions  from  local  governments  (27%).  The  cost  of  foreign  debt  was 
calculated on the basis of a nominal interest rate of 5.31%, an income tax rate of 33%, and an 
international inflation rate of 2.4% per year. The cost of local debt, on the other hand, assumed 
a  nominal  interest  rate  of  6.12%,  an  income  tax  rate  of  33%,  and  a  domestic  inflation  rate  of 
3.0% per year. The WACC was determined to be 3.01% for the base-case analysis.

8. 
The after-tax FIRR for the Project was estimated at 11.29% for the base-case scenario 
and between 7.58% and 12.36% for the various subprojects. These values compare favorably 
with  the  WACC  of  3.01%.  All  four  subprojects  are  financially  viable,  given  their  returns  to  net 
assets. Their debt-service coverage ratios are adequate.  
 
9. 
The  FIRR  estimates  for  the  Project  and  its  subprojects  seem  to  be  fairly  insensitive  to 
the variations tested in the sensitivity analysis. Increases in capital costs and in operation and 
maintenance  costs  have  the  greatest  impact  across  all  subprojects.  The  sensitivity  analysis 
suggests that tariff reform and improved financial management, particularly cost control, are the 
most important factors in assuring a successful project outcome.

Distribution of Project Costs and Benefits 

Project Tariffs 

D. 
 
The  direct  beneficiaries  include  0.24  million  below  the  official  poverty  line.  The  urban 
4. 
poor will derive disproportionately greater benefits from the Project since they generally live in 
poorly  served  neighborhoods  and  because  project  costs  are  relatively  heavier  on  enterprises 
and  better-off  households  in  view  of  government  funding  policies  and  poverty  alleviation 
policies. Poor households receive a lump-sum subsidy to offset the cost of wastewater services.  
 
E. 
 
Water  supply  tariffs  in  Wuhan  are  differentiated  by  consumer  category,  while  the 
5. 
wastewater tariff is the same for all customers. These tariffs have been increased significantly 
over the last 8 years, and wastewater tariffs are among the highest in large cities in the People’s 
Republic of China (PRC). Open public hearings are held to gain public support for tariffs. The 
use  of  public  hearings,  the  ongoing  tariff  increases,  and  the  introduction  of  wastewater  tariffs 
indicate that tariff reform promoted by the state Government is well under way in Wuhan. The 
estimated  tariff  increases  required  to  achieve  cost  recovery  are  modest,  and  the  combined 
water and wastewater bill is considered affordable, at less than 3% of household income for the 
poorest households. 
 
F. 
 
Generally, least-cost analysis appears not to be explicitly used in the master plan and in 
6. 
sector  plans,  standards,  and 
for  water  supply,  wastewater,  and  stormwater 
management, although least-cost concepts do seem to influence infrastructure planning. Least-
cost  analysis  can  be  used  in  the  future  when  drawing  up  urban  and  water  and  wastewater 
master  plans.  The  opportunity  exists  to  incorporate  least  cost  analysis  as  a  tool  in  future 
planning  exercises  at  the  stage  of  formulating  the  various  urban  and  water  and  wastewater 
master  plans.  A  supplementary  analysis  to  demonstrate  the  benefits  of  a  strategic  integrated 
approach  to  infrastructure  capacity  planning  was  undertaken.  This  work  will  have  carryover 
benefits when the TA Study on Sustainable Urbanization of Metropolitan Regions in the PRC2, 
which includes Wuhan as a case study city, is implemented starting in June 2006. If the Wuhan 
case study is successful, it could be replicated in other cities and provinces in the PRC. At the 
project  level,  the  least-cost  analysis  of  subprojects  accounted  for  the  incremental  costs  and 
benefits  over  the  economic  life  of  the  alternatives.  A  discount  rate  of 12%  was  used  to  reflect 
the  opportunity  cost  of  capital  in  the  PRC  in  calculations  of  net  present  value  and  average 
incremental economic costs.

These analyses confirmed that all but two of the subprojects were least-cost alternatives. 
7. 
The cost differentials for the two options that were not least-cost options were within the margin 
of error (2%–6%) for costing, and the subprojects chosen were preferred in any case since they 
were a better technical match for existing facilities. 
 
G. 
 
8. 
An economic evaluation was carried out for the Project as a whole and for its individual 
subprojects on a with- and without-project basis. Economic costs were estimated from financial 
costs but excluded price contingencies and all import duties and taxes while including physical 
contingencies.  Shadow  pricing  was  computed  for  all  costs  using  domestic  market  price 
conversion  factors  for  unskilled  labor  and  a  shadow  exchange  rate  factor.  All  financial 
projections were converted from nominal to real values by removing the effects of foreign and 
domestic inflation and currency fluctuations. The evaluation of benefits was based on industrial 
wastewater  treatment  costs  avoided,  residential  willingness  to  pay  for  wastewater  service 
improvements,  and  flood  damage  and  commercial  losses  averted.  EIRR  was  estimated  using 
incremental annual cash flows over a 20-year period of operations following the commissioning 
of works. The estimated EIRRs are presented in Tables A14.2 and A14.3. The combined EIRR 
(base case) for the five wastewater subprojects is 22.6%, ranging from 12.1% for the Nantaizi 
Lake wastewater treatment plant (WWTP) and collection system to 35.1% for the upgrading and 
expansion  of  the  Erlangmiao  WWTP.  Sensitivity  tests  indicate  generally  robust  results,  except 
for  Nantaizi  Lake  and  Huangpu  Road  when  costs  are  increased  by  10%  and  benefits  are 
delayed by 2 years.
